{{Infobox television |show_name = Chop Socky Boom |image = |caption = |genre = [[Comedy]] |creator = Darlene Sellers
Heath Ward |starring = Khanh Doan
Andrew McMasters
Jen Page
Jay Irwin
Brandon Ryan |composer = Matt Sayre |country = |language = English |num_seasons = 1 |num_episodes = 8 |list_episodes = |producer = |distributor = Frostbite Pictures |location = [[Seattle, WA]], [[US]] |runtime = 7-10 minutes |network = |first_aired = {{Start date|2012|5|1}} |last_aired = |website = http://www.chopsockyboom.com/ }} '''Chop Socky Boom''' is an award-winning comedy web series created by Darlene Sellers and Heath Ward and filmed in [[Seattle, Washington]]. The series is broadcast on the internet and premiered on May 1, 2012. Season one includes eight episodes, with season two currently under development. Chop Socky Boom follows the adventures of misfit [[indie film]] [[actors]] cast in the fictional [[kung fu film]], “Final Zodiac Warrior.” '''CSB''' focuses on main character Khanh and her friends, Scottie, Paige, Daisy and Max, as they audition for a poorly run [[chop socky]] series created by Trick, an [[Ed Wood]] like Director with his own unique vision.{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt2379647/fullcredits?ref_=tt_cl_sm#cast |title=IMDB - Chop Socky Boom Full Credits |publisher= IMDB.com |date= |accessdate= }} {{Cite web|url=http://cinemaontherocks.com/Webseries/chopsockyboom|title=Chop Socky Boom Review}}{{citation|journal=Surfing Aliens|author=Heather Cummings |date= March 7, 2013|title=CSB Review|url= http://surfingaliens.com/csbreview/}} == History == Chop Socky Boom was created by Sellers and Ward as a tribute to the adventures and misadventures of Seattle indie filmmaking.{{citation|journal=At Stake Magazine|author=Stacey Gillard |date= August 1, 2015|title=Chop Socky Boom, a Chat with the Creators|url= http://atstakemagazine.com/2014/08/01/chop-socky-boom-a-chat-with-the-creators-2//}} The first season was funded in part through a crowdfunding campaign {{ Cite web |url= https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/1569420893/chop-socky-boom-episodes-v-viii/|title=Chop Socky Boom episodes V-VIII}} and from a small grant awarded by [[4Culture]].{{ Cite web |url= http://www.4culture.org/about/past_awards/index.htm/|title=4Culture 2014 Award Recipients}} In May, 2012 CSB premiered on [[YouTube]] {{ Cite web |url= https://www.youtube.com/channel/UC1RvoQXdmAsRwfY3WA39mTQ/|title=Chop Socky Boom YouTube Channel}} and the Web Series Channel {{ Cite web |url=http://www.webserieschannel.com/chop-socky-boom/|title=Web series Channel: Chop Socky Boom}} and was featured by Zombie Orpheus Entertainment (ZOE), a distribution company created by [[Dead Gentlemen Productions]].{{ Cite web |url= http://zombieorpheus.com/shows/chop-socky-boom/|title=Zombie Orpheus Entertainment:Chop Socky Boom}} In 2014, CSB was picked up for distribution by Frostbite Pictures {{ Cite web |url= http://frostbitepictures.com/projects/chop-socky-boom/|title=Frostbite Show: Chop Socky Boom}} and is currently available on [http://www.jts.tv/ JTS.TV].{{ Cite web |url= http://www.jts.tv/previews/chop-socky-boom/|title=Chop Socky Boom on JTS.tv}} == Plot == Khanh is a talented, Seattle actress working hard to find her big break. She and eleven other local actors are cast in a new action show, “Final Zodiac Warrior.” '''FZW''' is a cross between [[Enter the Dragon]] and [[Highlander (film)|Highlander]] and features twelve warriors based on the [[Chinese zodiac]]. Portraying the signs of [[Rat (zodiac)|Rat]], [[Pig (zodiac)|Pig]], [[Rabbit (zodiac)|Rabbit]], [[Rooster (zodiac)|Rooster]] and [[Dragon (zodiac)|Dragon]], Khanh and her friends survive the indie film making process, all the while doing battle with their own individual demons. Be it mistreatment from their fabulous and beautiful cast member counterparts, ambiguous direction from the director Trick, or even the threat of looming unemployment at the day job, the misfits boldly fight the [[demons]].{{citation|journal=WebVee Guide|author=Kyle Price-Livington |date= March 31, 2014|title=Chop Socky Boom Review|url= http://webveeguide.com/reviews/2014/03/chop-socky-boom/}} ==Production== Principal photography takes place in [[Seattle, Washington]]. Locations include [[Kubota Gardens]], the [[Seattle Chinatown-International District]], [[Hing Hay Park (Seattle)]], the [[University District, Seattle|University District]], [[White Center, Washington]], [[Jet City Improv]], and Victory Studios.{{citation|journal=West Seattle Herald|date= May 1, 2012|title=Chop Socky Boom, New Web TV Ninja Spoof Showcases West Seattle|url= http://www.westseattleherald.com/2012/05/01/features/chop-socky-boom-new-web-tv-ninja-spoof-showca/}} ==Cast== {{div col|colwidth=30em}} *'''[[Khanh Doan]]''' as Khanh, the Red [[Dragon (zodiac)|Dragon]] *'''Andrew McMasters''' as Trick, the Director *'''Jen Page''' as Paige, the Pink [[Pig (zodiac)|Pig]] *'''Jay Irwin''' as Scottie, the Purple [[Rat (zodiac)|Rat]] *'''Darlene Sellers''' as Daisy, the Turquoise [[Rabbit (zodiac)|Rabbit]] *'''Brandon Ryan''' as Max, the PA *'''Lowell Deo''' as D'Angelo, the Gold [[Tiger (zodiac)|Tiger]] *'''Lisa Coronado''' as Eva, the Periwinkle [[Goat (zodiac)|Goat]] *'''Dan Humphrey''' as Charlie, the Blue [[Dog (zodiac)|Dog]] *'''S. Joe Downing''' as Dillon, the Bronze [[Ox (zodiac)|Ox]] *'''Eric Stevens''' as Ty, the Orange [[Horse (zodiac)|Horse]] *'''[[Terisa Greenan]]''' as Mitzi, the Casting Director *'''Shawn Telford''' as The '''CTBF''' ('''Cinema and Television Benevolent Fund''') is the leading [[United Kingdom|UK]] charity for people working behind the scenes in the film, cinema and television industries, whose careers cover all aspects of pre-production and beyond, from script to screen and in a variety of roles. For creatives, production professionals, marketers and administration staff, the CTBF exists for those with a need and it offers financial support to those who encounter accident, illness, bereavement or unemployment. Its chief executive is Richard Wilson.<ref>{{cite web|title=Richard Wilson appointed CEO of CTBF|url=http://www.screendaily.com/richard-wilson-appointed-ceo-of-ctbf/5048745.article|publisher=ScreenDaily.com|accessdate=7 November 2012}}</ref>
It raises money through events such as the [[Royal Film Performance]], an annual film evening attended by [[Elizabeth II|HM The Queen]] or other members of the British Royal Family, and from membership subscriptions and donations.
As well as helping those who have worked in the Film and TV industries, the CTBF also supports up and coming talent in Film and TV through the [http://www.jbawards.org.uk JBAs] (John Brabourne Awards), which provides financial assistance of between £1000 and £5000.

revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=August 2008}} {{Infobox album | name = Cryptic Collection 2 | type = compilation | artist = [[Twiztid]] | cover = MADROX_COVER_CC2.gif | alt = | caption = Madrox Cover | released = {{Start date|2001|10|22}} | recorded = | venue = | studio = | genre = {{hlist|[[Horrorcore]]|[[hardcore hip hop]]|[[indie hip hop]]}} | length = {{duration|m=42|s=19}} | label = [[Psychopathic Records]] | producer = | prev_title = [[Cryptic Collection]] | prev_year = 2000 | next_title = [[Mirror Mirror (EP)|Mirror Mirror]] | next_year = 2002 | misc = {{Extra album cover | header = ''Alternate cover'' | type = compilation | cover = Cryptic_collection_monoxide_cover.jpg | border = | alt = | caption = Monoxide Cover }} }} '''''Cryptic Collection 2''''' is a [[compilation album]] by [[Twiztid]]. Released on October 22, 2001, it is the second in the Cryptic Collection series, followed by ''[[Cryptic Collection Vol. 3]]'', each containing rare tracks not available on regular releases.{{cite web |url={{Allmusic|class=album|id=r690470|pure_url=yes}} |title=Review of ''Cryptic Collection, Vol. 3'' |accessdate=2008-08-22 |last=Loftus |first=Johnny |publisher=[[Allmusic]]}} [[File:CC2_REISSUE_COVER.gif.png|thumb|''Cryptic Collection 2'' was later reissued with a new cover, combining the original two.]] == Track listing == {| class="wikitable" |- !align="center" width="10"|# !align="center" width="220"|Title !align="center" width="20"|Time !align="center" width="110"|Performer(s) |- |1 |"Freek Show Intro 2" |1:11 |- |2 |"Murder, Murder, Murder" |3:19 |[[Twiztid]] |- |3 |"Liquid Friend" |3:29 |Mr. Bones |- |4 |"I Remember" |2:49 |Twiztid |- |5 |"Smoke Break" |0:21 |Violent J |- |6 |"Why the Children?" |3:17 |Mr. Bones |- |7 |"I Don't Care" |3:44 |Twiztid
[[Insane Clown Posse]] |- |8 |"She Ain't Afraid" |5:57 |Twiztid
[[Shaggy 2 Dope]] |- |9 |"Home Bound" |2:07 |[[House of Krazees]] |- |10 |"Unrational" |3:34 |Mr. Bones |- |11 |"We Don't Die" (Non-Rock Version) |3:16 |Twiztid |- |12 |"Anotha Smoke Break" |0:21 |Violent J |- |13 |"Juggalo Party" |4:35 |Twiztid
[[Drive-By (group)|Drive-By]] |- |14 |"Drunken Ninja Master" |4:18 |'''[[Dark Lotus]]''' |} Tracks: 2, 5, 8, and 12, were all tracks from the original Mostasteless release from 1997. Tracks: 3, 6. and 10, were tracks done by Mr. Bones (Jamie Madrox) from his release: Sacrifice Tracks: 1, 4, 7, and 11, were all cut from Twiztid's 2000 release: Freek Show Track: 9 was an old House of Krazee's track from their second album : Homebound Track: 13 was a Twiztid track with Blaze Ya Dead Homie which was released as a single at Hallowicked 2000. Track: 14 was a Dark Lotus track made for the album ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Twiztid}} [[Category:B-side compilation albums]] [[Category:Twiztid compilation albums]] [[Category:2001 compilation albums]] [[Category:Psychopathic Records compilation albums]] [[Category:Sequel albums]] {{2001-hiphop-album-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox television season | show_name = Degrassi | season_number = 10 | bgcolour = | image = DegrassiSeason10completeDVD.JPG | image_alt = | caption = ''Degrassi'' Season 10 DVD | starring = | country = Canada | num_episodes = 44 | network = [[Much (TV channel)|MuchMusic]] (Canada)
[[TeenNick]] (United States) | first_aired = {{start date|2010|07|19}} | last_aired = {{end date|2011|04|22}} | prev_season = [[Degrassi: The Next Generation (season 9)|Season 9]] | episode_list = List of Degrassi: The Next Generation episodes }} The '''tenth season of ''Degrassi'' ''' premiered in Canada on July 19, 2010, concluded on April 22, 2011, and consists of 44 episodes. ''[[Degrassi: The Next Generation|Degrassi]]'' is a Canadian serial [[teen drama]] television series. Previously known as ''Degrassi: The Next Generation'',{{cite web |url=http://www.ctv.ca/CTVNews/Entertainment/20100715/transgender-in-degrassi-100715 |title='Degrassi' tackles transgender storyline |author=The Canadian Press |date=July 15, 2010 |work=CTV News |accessdate=July 15, 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100716194114/http://www.ctv.ca/CTVNews/Entertainment/20100715/transgender-in-degrassi-100715/ |archivedate=July 16, 2010 |df=mdy }} the suffix "the Next Generation" was dropped this season, due to the original ''next'' generation of students having all been written out. With the start of the tenth season, the series has survived longer than the nine-year gap between ''[[Degrassi High]]'''s telemovie ''[[School's Out (1992 film)|School's Out]]'', and ''Degrassi''’s premiere episode "[[Mother and Child Reunion (Degrassi: The Next Generation)|Mother and Child Reunion]]". Although only two [[Academic term#Canada|school years]] have passed in the story timeline since season six, season ten is set in the first semester, and first half of the second semester, in which the years it aired. Writers have been able to use a semi-[[floating timeline]], so that the issues depicted are modern for their viewers. This season depicts the lives of a group of high school [[Tenth grade|sophomores]], [[Eleventh grade|juniors]], [[Twelfth grade|seniors]], and [[graduate diploma|graduates]] as they deal with some of the challenges and issues that teenagers face such as [[domestic violence]], [[dysfunctional families]], [[body image|self image]], [[bullying]], [[sexual harassment]], [[gender identity]]/[[transsexualism]], [[teenage pregnancy]], [[online predator]]s, [[homophobia]], [[school violence]], [[divorce]], [[religion]], [[kidney failure]], [[self-harm]], [[alcoholism]], [[sexual identity]], financial difficulties, running away and relationships. This season doubled the order of episodes, and switched to a [[telenovela]]/[[soap opera]] format, with the show airing new episodes four days a week, for the first 24 episodes.{{cite web|last=Stohn|first=Stephen|title=Tweet 48730418761048064|url=https://twitter.com/stephenstohn/status/48730418761048064|publisher=Twitter|accessdate=March 18, 2011|date=March 18, 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/entertainment/tv/2010/03/12/2010-03-12_testing_soapy_waters_nickelodeon_to_use_degrassi_the_next_generation_to_try_out_.html#ixzz0hykkjzy5 |title=Testing soap-y waters: Nickelodeon to use 'Degrassi: The Next Generation' to try out telenovelas |author=Richard Huff |date=March 12, 2010 |work=NY Daily News |accessdate=March 24, 2010}} Production for the season began on March 26, 2010{{cite web |url=http://degrassiblog.com/2010/03/06/degrassi-season-10-starts-shooting-march-26/ |title=Degrassi Season 10 Starts Shooting March 26 |date=March 6, 2010 |publisher=DegrassiBlog.com |accessdate=March 24, 2010}} at [[Epitome Pictures]]' studios in [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]]. This was the first season not to air on [[broadcast television]]. It is also the first season to have simultaneous airings in Canada and the United States.{{cite web |url=https://twitter.com/stephenstohn/status/10745657024 |title=Tweet 10745657024 |author=Stephen Stohn |date=March 19, 2010 |publisher=Twitter |accessdate=March 30, 2010}} This was the earliest start to a season. In the US, the first 24 episodes of season ten were promoted as ''Degrassi: The Boiling Point'', while the final twelve episodes of the season were promoted as ''Degrassi: In Too Deep''.{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FfRF8HkKA4A |title=Degrassi: In Too Deep |publisher=TeenNick |accessdate=January 17, 2011}} The fifth Degrassi dedicated [[soundtrack]], ''[[Degrassi: The Boiling Point (Music from the Series)|Degrassi: The Boiling Point]]'', was released February 1, 2011. ==Cast and characters== {{main|List of Degrassi: The Next Generation characters}} The tenth season features twenty-four actors who receive star billing with sixteen of them returning from the previous season. Returning cast members include: {{Div col|colwidth=30em}} * Raymond Ablack as [[Sav Bhandari]] (33 episodes) * [[Charlotte Arnold]] as [[Holly J. Sinclair]] (33 episodes) * [[Stefan Brogren]] as [[Archie "Snake" Simpson]] (20 episodes) * Annie Clark as [[Fiona Coyne (Degrassi character)|Fiona Coyne]] (26 episodes) * Sam Earle as [[K.C. Guthrie]] (25 episodes) * Jahmil French as [[Dave Turner (Degrassi)|Dave Turner]] (29 episodes) * Judy Jiao as [[Leia Chang]] (2 episodes) * [[Jamie Johnston]] as [[Peter Stone (Degrassi character)|Peter Stone]] (4 episodes) * Argiris Karras as [[Riley Stavros]] (13 episodes) * [[Landon Liboiron]] as [[Declan Coyne]] (9 episodes) * Jajube Mandiela as [[Chantay Black]] (19 episodes) * [[Samantha Munro]] as [[Anya MacPherson]] (27 episodes) * [[Aislinn Paul]] as [[Clare Edwards]] (35 episodes) * [[A.J. Saudin]] as [[Connor Deslauriers]] (20 episodes) * [[Melinda Shankar]] as [[Alli Bhandari]] (31 episodes) * Jessica Tyler as [[Jenna Middleton]] (24 episodes) {{div col end}} Beginning this season, Stefan Brogren is the only original cast member to still appear in the series. Joining the main cast this season are: {{Div col}} * Luke Bilyk as [[Drew Torres]] (26 episodes) * [[Munro Chambers]] as [[Eli Goldsworthy]] (27 episodes) * Alicia Josipovic as [[Bianca DeSousa]] (19 episodes) * [[Cory Lee]] as [[Winnie Oh|Ms. Oh]] (25 episodes) * [[Jordan Todosey]] as [[Adam Torres (Degrassi: The Next Generation)|Adam Torres]] (25 episodes) * Spencer Van Wyck as [[Wesley Betenkamp]] (28 episodes) (promoted after appearing in a season nine episode) {{div col end}} Half-way through the season, recurring actors [[Shannon Kook|Shannon Kook-Chun]] and Daniel Kelly who play [[Zane Park]] (13 episodes) and [[Owen Milligan]] (12 episodes) were promoted to the main cast while [[Jamie Johnston]] and Judy Jiao departed. The nine actors from season nine who did not return this season were: {{Div col|colwidth=30em}} * Dalmar Abuzeid as [[Danny Van Zandt]] * [[Paula Brancati]] as [[Jane Vaughn (Degrassi character)|Jane Vaughn]] * Jordan Hudyma as [[Blue Chessex]] * [[Shane Kippel]] as [[Spinner Mason]] * [[Mike Lobel]] as [[Jay Hogart]] * [[Miriam McDonald]] as [[Emma Nelson]] * Scott Paterson as [[Johnny DiMarco]] * [[Cassie Steele]] as [[Manny Santos (Degrassi: The Next Generation)|Manny Santos]] * and Natty Zavitz as [[Bruce the Moose]] {{div col end}} All left the series except for Scott Paterson, who made a guest appearance in the season and Shane Kippel who made a guest appearance in season 14. ==Crew== Season ten was produced by [[Epitome Pictures]] in association with Much/CTV. Funding was provided by [[Canada Media Fund|The Canadian Media Fund]], [[Royal Bank of Canada|RBC Royal Bank]], The Shaw Rocket Fund, The Independent Production Fund: Mountain Cable Program, The Canadian Film or Video Production Tax Credit, and the Ontario Film and Television Tax Credit. [[Linda Schuyler]], co-creator of the ''Degrassi'' franchise and CEO of Epitome Pictures, served as an [[executive producer]] with her husband, and President of Epitome Pictures, [[Stephen Stohn]]. Brendon Yorke is also credited as an executive producer, and Sarah Glinski is credited as a co-executive producer. David Lowe and Stefan Brogren are the producers, and Stephanie Williams the supervising producer. The casting director is Stephanie Gorin, and the editors are Jason B. Irvine, Gordon Thorne, and Paul Whitehead. The executive story editors are Duana Taha and Matt Huether, the story editors are Michael Grassi and Cole Bastedo, and Lauren Gosnell is the story coordinator. Episode writers for the season are Cole Bastedo, Sarah Glinski, Michael Grassi, Matt Huether, James Hurst, Vera Santamaria, Shelly Scarrow, Duana Taha, and Brendon Yorke. The director of photography is Alwyn J. Kumst, and the directors are Mario Azzopardi, Stefan Brogren, Phil Earnshaw, Sturla Gunnarsson, Eleanore Lindo, Samir Rehem, Stefan Scaini, and Pat Williams. ==Episodes== The first run, of 24 episodes, began after the feature-length film ''[[Degrassi Takes Manhattan]]'' in July 2010, and ran for six weeks.{{cite web |url=https://twitter.com/stephenstohn/status/10718739322 |title=Tweet 10718739322 |author=Stephen Stohn |date=March 19, 2010 |publisher=Twitter |accessdate=March 30, 2010}} This is also the first season that the episodes aired on the same nights in Canada and the United States, with the exception being the first week, when the United States was one day behind Canada. This is the first time that the opening credits have been revised halfway through the season, and was repeated for season 11 and 12. {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="width:100%; margin:auto;" |- ! style="background-color: #145; color:#fff; text-align: center;" width="20"|No. in
season ! style="background-color: #145; color:#fff; text-align: center;" width="20"|No. in
series ! style="background-color: #145; color:#fff; text-align: center;"|Title ! style="background-color: #145; color:#fff; text-align: center;" width="120"|Canadian airdate ! style="background-color: #145; color:#fff; text-align: center;" width="120"|US airdate ! style="background-color: #145; color:#fff; text-align: center;" width="70"|Production code {{Episode list/sublist|Degrassi (season 10) | LineColor=145 | EpisodeNumber=1 | EpisodeNumber2=189 | Title=What a Girl Wants | RTitle= Part One | OriginalAirDate={{start date|2010|7|19}} | AltDate=July 20, 2010 | ProdCode=1001 | ShortSummary= Holly J. is back for her senior year at Degrassi with a mission to be student council president, but when Sav decides to run against her, Holly J. grows worried when he proves to be popular among the students. Meanwhile, Fiona prepares for a drama-free school year until her new boyfriend, Bobby becomes too controlling. Also, Dave makes a list of the hottest Degrassi girls to impress Alli, but there is an error in the computer programming, and Alli is ranked low. }} {{Episode list/sublist|Degrassi (season 10) | LineColor=145 | EpisodeNumber=2 | EpisodeNumber2=190 | Title=What a Girl Wants | RTitle= Part Two | OriginalAirDate={{start date|2010|7|20}} | AltDate=July 21, 2010 | ProdCode=1002 | ShortSummary= Fiona forgives Bobby for hitting her until she finds out he is cheating on her with his ex-girlfriend, Tinsley. Feeling alone, she is left with a difficult decision. Meanwhile, Holly J. enlists Anya to fake a pregnancy in order to make Sav quit the election. However, Sav uses it to his benefit and vows to Anya that he will be there for her while she's "carrying" his child. Also, in order to exact revenge, Alli decides to make a "Biggest Losers" list and puts Dave at the top. }} {{Episode list/sublist|Degrassi (season 10) | LineColor=145 | EpisodeNumber=3 | EpisodeNumber2=191 | Title=Breakaway | RTitle= Part One | OriginalAirDate={{start date|2010|7|21}} | AltDate=July 22, 2010 | ProdCode=1003 | ShortSummary= When Fiona feels like she has no one to turn to and realizes she cannot handle the scrutiny in New York, she runs to the only friend she can trust. Meanwhile, Anya has to come clean to Sav and reveal that Holly J. talked her into faking a pregnancy in order to make him drop out of the race. Also, Jenna starts a rumor when she overhears a conversation involving surgery between Clare and Alli. }} {{Episode list/sublist|Degrassi (season 10) | LineColor=145 | EpisodeNumber=4 | EpisodeNumber2=192 | Title=Breakaway | RTitle= Part Two | OriginalAirDate={{start date|2010|7|22}} | AltDate=July 23, 2010 | ProdCode=1004 | ShortSummary= Holly J. has to take a [[SAT]] prep course in order to get into Yale, but due to her family's financial difficulties, she cannot afford it. She now must decide if she's willing to risk Fiona's friendship to get what she wants. Meanwhile, Anya and Sav face the difficult decision of telling everyone that they faked her pregnancy. Also, Clare finds out about Jenna's rumor after a rather personal encounter with Wesley. }} {{Episode list/sublist|Degrassi (season 10) | LineColor=145 | EpisodeNumber=5 | EpisodeNumber2=193 | Title=99 Problems | RTitle= Part One | OriginalAirDate={{start date|2010|7|26}} | AltDate=July 26, 2010 | ProdCode=1005 | ShortSummary= Riley competes with new student Drew for the first quarterback position on the football team. When Drew overhears a conversation between Riley and Zane, he blackmails Riley. Meanwhile, Alli tries out for the Power Squad to be in the popular crowd but finds out how tough Chantay is. Also, K.C. is becoming more popular with the girls after joining the football team and triggers Jenna's jealousy. }} {{Episode list/sublist|Degrassi (season 10) | LineColor=145 | EpisodeNumber=6 | EpisodeNumber2=194 | Title=99 Problems | RTitle= Part Two | OriginalAirDate={{start date|2010|7|27}} | AltDate=July 27, 2010 | ProdCode=1006 | ShortSummary= Riley takes his feud with Drew too far, putting his position on the football team and relationship with Zane in jeopardy. Meanwhile, Alli makes a dance troupe to rival the Power Squad. But her plan backfires due to her own attitude. Also, Jenna's jealousy gets the best of her when she searches K.C.'s phone and finds something interesting. }} {{Episode list/sublist|Degrassi (season 10) | LineColor=145 | EpisodeNumber=7 | EpisodeNumber2=195 | Title=Better Off Alone | RTitle= Part One | OriginalAirDate={{start date|2010|7|28}} | AltDate=July 28, 2010 | ProdCode=1007 | ShortSummary= K.C.'s mother comes back into his life and reveals that she is seeking custody of him. K.C. decides to do whatever it takes to ensure that he stays at the group home. Meanwhile, in English class, Clare's struggles with writing about non-vampire topics leads her to a writing partner, Eli, who convinces her to break out of her shell and express herself. Also, Alli asks Dave for guy advice, but he misunderstands which guy she means. }} {{Episode list/sublist|Degrassi (season 10) | LineColor=145 | EpisodeNumber=8 | EpisodeNumber2=196 | Title=Better Off Alone | RTitle= Part Two | OriginalAirDate={{start date|2010|7|29}} | AltDate=July 29, 2010 | ProdCode=1008 | ShortSummary= K.C.'s resistance at moving back in with his mother leads to lashing out at the wrong people, and the person who helps him pick up the pieces is the last person he expects. Meanwhile, when she is worried that her parents might be heading for divorce, Eli convinces Clare to express her feelings through her writing. Also, Alli considers Drew to be her boyfriend, but that might be news to him. }} {{Episode list/sublist|Degrassi (season 10) | LineColor=145 | EpisodeNumber=9 | EpisodeNumber2=197 | Title=I Just Don't Know What to Do with Myself | RTitle= Part One | OriginalAirDate={{start date|2010|8|2}} | AltDate=August 2, 2010 | ProdCode=1009 | ShortSummary= Sav desperately tries to prove to his parents that he is responsible enough to go to a concert but runs into unforeseen circumstances. Meanwhile, Jenna obsesses over her weight for the upcoming Power Squad Calendar photo shoot when she can't fit into her uniform. Also, Fiona's loneliness leads her to an unlikely companion. }} {{Episode list/sublist|Degrassi (season 10) | LineColor=145 | EpisodeNumber=10 | EpisodeNumber2=198 | Title=I Just Don't Know What to Do with Myself | RTitle= Part Two | OriginalAirDate={{start date|2010|8|3}} | AltDate=August 3, 2010 | ProdCode=1010 | ShortSummary= Tired of his parents' strict rules, Sav comes up with the perfect plan in order to take his father's truck out to the concert with Adam and Eli. Meanwhile, Jenna tries diet pills and suffers humiliating results. Also, Fiona's pet pig Porcelina messes up her apartment. }} {{Episode list/sublist|Degrassi (season 10) | LineColor=145 | EpisodeNumber=11 | EpisodeNumber2=199 | Title=Try Honesty | RTitle= Part One | OriginalAirDate={{start date|2010|8|4}} | AltDate=August 4, 2010 | ProdCode=1011 | ShortSummary=Declan plans a road trip to [[Yale University]], but Holly J. can't afford it. Later on, Holly J. begins to think that Declan is cheating on her when she sees cozy pictures of Declan and Tinsley online. Meanwhile, Eli gets himself involved in a feud with school bully, Fitz. Also, Dave, Wesley and Connor form a band as a way to get girls, but they soon run into an unexpected problem. }} {{Episode list/sublist|Degrassi (season 10) | LineColor=145 | EpisodeNumber=12 | EpisodeNumber2=200 | Title=Try Honesty | RTitle= Part Two | OriginalAirDate={{start date|2010|8|5}} | AltDate=August 5, 2010 | ProdCode=1012 | ShortSummary= Declan returns to town and begins offering financial help to Holly J. But when she starts to feel like a kept woman, Holly J. must choose between her relationship with Declan and her self-respect. Meanwhile, Eli puts his plan for revenge into effect, starting a war between him and Fitz. Also, Connor and Wesley enlist Sav's help in auto-tuning Dave's horrible singing. ---- '''Note:''' This is the 200th episode in ''The Next Generation'' series, and the number 200 was said in dialogue three times.'''Declan:''' "Only 200 more days 'till graduation though." {{Cite episode |title=Try Honesty, Part 2 |episodelink=#ep12 |url=http://www.muchmusic.com/tv/degrassi/episodes/episode1012.aspx |series=Degrassi |network=[[MuchMusic]] |airdate=August 5, 2010 |number=1012 |minutes=2:31}}
'''Holly J.:''' It's okay, 'cause he's here, and I am 200% more happy." {{Cite episode |title=Try Honesty, Part 2 |episodelink=#ep12 |url=http://www.muchmusic.com/tv/degrassi/episodes/episode1012.aspx |series=Degrassi |network=[[MuchMusic]] |airdate=August 5, 2010 |number=1012 |minutes=5:07}}
'''Holly J.:''' I have to work 200 times harder to get what I want, thanks to yours and Dad's mistakes." {{Cite episode |title=Try Honesty, Part 2 |episodelink=#ep12 |url=http://www.muchmusic.com/tv/degrassi/episodes/episode1012.aspx |series=Degrassi |network=[[MuchMusic]] |airdate=August 5, 2010 |number=1012 |minutes=9:59}} }} {{Episode list/sublist|Degrassi (season 10) | LineColor=145 | EpisodeNumber=13 | EpisodeNumber2=201 | Title=You Don't Know My Name | RTitle= Part One | OriginalAirDate={{start date|2010|8|9}} | AltDate=August 9, 2010 | ProdCode=1013 | ShortSummary= Alli wants to be in an official relationship with Drew, and in order to prove that she is worthy of being his girlfriend, she does his history assignment for him. Sav and Holly J work together on a dance for Above the Dot, and realize that they may have feelings for each other. Connor is staying up all night and playing an online role playing game, over which he has met a girl. }} {{Episode list/sublist|Degrassi (season 10) | LineColor=145 | EpisodeNumber=14 | EpisodeNumber2=202 | Title=You Don't Know My Name | RTitle= Part Two | OriginalAirDate={{start date|2010|8|10}} | AltDate=August 10, 2010 | ProdCode=1014 | ShortSummary= Drew realizes how much he likes Alli and attempts to win her back when she starts playing hard to get. In Holly J.'s mind, she knows that she and Sav can only be friends, but her heart begins telling her differently. Connor is in for a surprise when he meets his online girlfriend in real life. }} {{Episode list/sublist|Degrassi (season 10) | LineColor=145 | EpisodeNumber=15 | EpisodeNumber2=203 | Title=[[My Body Is a Cage]] | RTitle= Part One | OriginalAirDate={{start date|2010|8|11}} | AltDate=August 11, 2010 | ProdCode=1015 | ShortSummary= Adam just wants to be a normal boy in high school but soon realizes that it will be impossible when his classmates start finding out that he is a female-to-male [[transgender]]. Leia convinces a suspicious Anya to believe that her mother is having an affair but discovers that it's even worse. Dave attempts to get on Ms. Oh's good side and decides to do a little research on her. ---- '''Guest star:''' [[Jean-Marc Généreux]] as gym instructor. }} {{Episode list/sublist|Degrassi (season 10) | LineColor=145 | EpisodeNumber=16 | EpisodeNumber2=204 | Title=[[My Body Is a Cage]] | RTitle= Part Two | OriginalAirDate={{start date|2010|8|12}} | AltDate=August 12, 2010 | ProdCode=1016 | ShortSummary= After realizing what his life would now be like, Adam appeases his family and fellow students by [[Transsexualism#Regrets and detransitions|detransitioning]] back into "Gracie," which unbeknownst to them brings back a harmful old habit. Meanwhile, Anya struggles with finding out that her mother has cancer, which comes at a bad time when she has to do a project with two people whom she doesn't want to see: Sav and Holly J. Also, Dave wonders what is wrong with Ms. Oh. ---- '''Guest star:''' [[Jean-Marc Généreux]] as gym instructor. '''Note:''' This is the 300th episode in the [[Degrassi (franchise)|''Degrassi'' franchise]]. }} {{Episode list/sublist|Degrassi (season 10) | LineColor=145 | EpisodeNumber=17 | EpisodeNumber2=205 | Title=Tears Dry on Their Own | RTitle= Part One | OriginalAirDate={{start date|2010|8|16}} | AltDate=August 16, 2010 | ProdCode=1017 | ShortSummary= Alli thinks Jenna is pregnant when she starts showing symptoms, but she is too worried about her audition for Next Teen Star to take these symptoms seriously. Connor reconnects with his older online love, which leaves Wesley and Dave worried. Riley avoids the football team and Zane and hangs out with Anya. }} {{Episode list/sublist|Degrassi (season 10) | LineColor=145 | EpisodeNumber=18 | EpisodeNumber2=206 | Title=Tears Dry on Their Own | RTitle= Part Two | OriginalAirDate={{start date|2010|8|17}} | AltDate=August 17, 2010 | ProdCode=1018 | ShortSummary= Jenna finds out that she is pregnant, and with her parents out of the picture and just her brother on whom to rely, she seeks comfort in K.C., only to find out that he expects her to get an abortion. Meanwhile, Connor secretly contacts his online girlfriend and makes plans to see her. Also, Anya and Riley are both attracted to her mother's doctor and investigate to find out for which team he plays. }} {{Episode list/sublist|Degrassi (season 10) | LineColor=145 | EpisodeNumber=19 | EpisodeNumber2=207 | Title=Still Fighting It | RTitle= Part One | OriginalAirDate={{start date|2010|8|18}} | AltDate=August 18, 2010 | ProdCode=1019 | ShortSummary= Riley attempts to fit in with the guys on the football team, but when he sees how "harmless" gay jokes affect Zane, he decides it's time to take a stand. Sparks fly between Eli and Clare, but Eli soon gives Clare mixed signals. In exchange for tutelage, Drew helps Wesley to be cool in order to impress Anya. }} {{Episode list/sublist|Degrassi (season 10) | LineColor=145 | EpisodeNumber=20 | EpisodeNumber2=208 | Title=Still Fighting It | RTitle= Part Two | OriginalAirDate={{start date|2010|8|19}} | AltDate=August 19, 2010 | ProdCode=1020 | ShortSummary= Riley risks his renewed relationship with Zane when he violently overreacts to Owen's homophobic comments. Meanwhile, Clare is determined to get to the bottom of Eli's mysterious secret. Also, Drew tries to teach Wesley to be more confident just in time for an Eligible Bachelor's Auction at school. }} {{Episode list/sublist|Degrassi (season 10) | LineColor=145 | EpisodeNumber=21 | EpisodeNumber2=209 | Title=Purple Pills | RTitle= Part One | OriginalAirDate={{start date|2010|8|23}} | AltDate=August 23, 2010 | ProdCode=1021 | ShortSummary= Fiona becomes stressed when she has to record her testimony against Bobby and self-medicates by drinking champagne, which could put the school's biggest event of the year in jeopardy. Meanwhile, Riley is finally ready to make his relationship with Zane official, but he's afraid that coming out might ruin the mood for the upcoming football game. Also, Adam is feeling rejected by Eli, now that he is involved with Clare, and decides to befriend Fitz. }} {{Episode list/sublist|Degrassi (season 10) | LineColor=145 | EpisodeNumber=22 | EpisodeNumber2=210 | Title=Purple Pills | RTitle= Part Two | OriginalAirDate={{start date|2010|8|24}} | AltDate=August 24, 2010 | ProdCode=1022 | ShortSummary= Fiona continues to drink champagne as a coping mechanism, which could ruin her deposition against Bobby and her exams. Meanwhile, Riley must decide if he's ready to be a poster boy for gay athletes when he is scouted for college football. Also, Adam doesn't like the way Fitz treats him and decides to do something about it. }} {{Episode list/sublist|Degrassi (season 10) | LineColor=145 | EpisodeNumber=23 | EpisodeNumber2=211 | Title=All Falls Down | RTitle= Part One | OriginalAirDate={{start date|2010|8|25}} | AltDate=August 25, 2010 | ProdCode=1023 | ShortSummary= When Bianca begins flirting with him, Drew must decide whether to remain faithful to his girlfriend, Alli, or give into temptation. Clare has had enough of the Eli/Fitz rivalry and decides to put a stop to it. Sav and Holly J. have to convince Mr. Simpson to ignore the PTA ruling to cancel the "Night in Vegas" dance by promising to keep the event trouble-free. }} {{Episode list/sublist|Degrassi (season 10) | LineColor=145 | EpisodeNumber=24 | EpisodeNumber2=212 | Title=All Falls Down | RTitle= Part Two | OriginalAirDate={{start date|2010|8|26}} | AltDate=August 26, 2010 | ProdCode=1024 | ShortSummary= Degrassi will never be the same after the "Night in Vegas" dance: Alli finds out about Drew's indiscretion with Bianca in the boiler room and decides to get back at him by doing something she may regret forever; growing closer to each other, Holly J. and Sav sneak out of the dance to have a little fun, and the feud between Eli and Fitz gets out of hand and reaches a serious level of violence--possibly even fatal. }} {{Episode list/sublist|Degrassi (season 10) | LineColor=145 | EpisodeNumber=25 | EpisodeNumber2=213 | Title=Don't Let Me Get Me | RTitle= Part One | OriginalAirDate={{start date|2010|10|8}} | AltDate=October 8, 2010 | ProdCode=1025 | ShortSummary= The students return from winter break to find out Degrassi is under the weight of a major discipline crackdown. Meanwhile, Alli must deal with an increasing rumor that she had inappropriate relations at the school at Vegas night. Also, Jenna feels pressured to have a sob story to garner votes in Next Teen Star. }} {{Episode list/sublist|Degrassi (season 10) | LineColor=145 | EpisodeNumber=26 | EpisodeNumber2=214 | Title=Don't Let Me Get Me | RTitle= Part Two | OriginalAirDate={{start date|2010|10|8}} | AltDate=October 8, 2010 | ProdCode=1026 | ShortSummary= Alli's past indiscretions at Degrassi comes back to haunt her, causing her reevaluate her life and make a difficult decision about her future. Meanwhile, after Jenna reveals her pregnancy on Next Teen Star, she is now forced to deal with the fact that she will soon be a teen mom. }} {{Episode list/sublist|Degrassi (season 10) | LineColor=145 | EpisodeNumber=27 | EpisodeNumber2=215 | Title=Love Lockdown | RTitle= Part One | OriginalAirDate={{start date|2010|10|15}} | AltDate=October 15, 2010 | ProdCode=1027 | ShortSummary= Declan has returned from New York to attend the Grundy Awards and to win back Holly J. Finding out that she is now with Sav, it proves more difficult. Meanwhile, Clare's parents want to have the dreaded "family talk" on the same night as her first real date with Eli. Also, Chantay tries to fight to keep the Power Squad running. }} {{Episode list/sublist|Degrassi (season 10) | LineColor=145 | EpisodeNumber=28 | EpisodeNumber2=216 | Title=Love Lockdown | RTitle= Part Two | OriginalAirDate={{start date|2010|10|22}} | AltDate=October 22, 2010 | ProdCode=1028 | ShortSummary= Holly J. is conflicted over what she did with Declan at his party and doesn't know if it was just bad decision or something much worse--like rape. Meanwhile, Clare uses her newfound rebellion and her dark boyfriend, Eli, as a way to create common ground between her parents and get them back together. Also, after finding out about the other clubs, Chantay rallies everyone together to take a stand against Mr. Simpson. }} {{Episode list/sublist|Degrassi (season 10) | LineColor=145 | EpisodeNumber=29 | EpisodeNumber2=217 | Title=Umbrella | RTitle= Part One | OriginalAirDate={{start date|2010|10|29}} | AltDate=October 29, 2010 | ProdCode=1029 | ShortSummary= Clare's parents are divorcing whether she likes it or not. Feeling totally uneasy and irrelevant in her own home, she's despondent, but Eli's parents have a strange offer. Meanwhile, Drew and Adam run a food drive and ask Fiona to volunteer, but both are attracted to her and try to flirt with her. Also, Dave's police officer father is stationed at Degrassi, and Wes does not understand why Dave is embarrassed. }} {{Episode list/sublist|Degrassi (season 10) | LineColor=145 | EpisodeNumber=30 | EpisodeNumber2=218 | Title=Umbrella | RTitle= Part Two | OriginalAirDate={{start date|2010|11|5}} | AltDate=November 5, 2010 | ProdCode=1030 | ShortSummary= Clare and Eli's differences continue to clash, but she soon discovers the shocking answer to all of her questions about Eli. Meanwhile, Adam continues to grow jealous of the flirting between Drew and Fiona. Also, Dave will do anything he can to prove to his new friends that he is nothing like his dad, even if he hurts Wesley in the process. }} {{Episode list/sublist|Degrassi (season 10) | LineColor=145 | EpisodeNumber=31 | EpisodeNumber2=219 | Title=Halo | RTitle= Part One | OriginalAirDate={{start date|2010|11|12}} | AltDate=November 12, 2010 | ProdCode=1031 | ShortSummary= Jenna feels alone in her pregnancy but finds that Sav is the one guy that is willing to give his time for her. True, he's dating Holly J., but that won't stop Jenna. Meanwhile, K.C. and Drew like the same girl. Also, Wesley and Anya plan their date, but he begins to worry about premature ejaculation after having a wet dream. And Adam tries to impress Fiona after she begins missing dances in New York. }} {{Episode list/sublist|Degrassi (season 10) | LineColor=145 | EpisodeNumber=32 | EpisodeNumber2=220 | Title=Halo | RTitle= Part Two | OriginalAirDate={{start date|2010|11|19}} | AltDate=November 19, 2010 | ProdCode=1032 | ShortSummary= Jenna puts Sav and Holly J.'s relationship in jeopardy when she attempts to steal Sav away, and all the while K.C. begins having feelings for Jenna again. Meanwhile, Wesley's little problem erupts when he purchases a sexual endurance drug for his date with Anya. Meanwhile, Adam, with the help of Clare and Eli, organizes a secret party for Degrassi students with the intention of impressing Fiona. }} {{Episode list/sublist|Degrassi (season 10) | LineColor=145 | EpisodeNumber=33 | EpisodeNumber2=221 | Title=When Love Takes Over | RTitle= Part One | OriginalAirDate={{start date|2011|2|11}} | AltDate=February 11, 2011 | ProdCode=1033 | ShortSummary= It is Sweetheart Week at Degrassi. Meanwhile, Adam and Fiona begin to reconnect when he suggests she try out for a part in the school play. Also, after Anya's mother's cancer has disappeared, Anya pursues a relationship with the eight-years-older doctor. And Dave meets Sadie, and they make a date, but he finds out she is much taller than him. }} {{Episode list/sublist|Degrassi (season 10) | LineColor=145 | EpisodeNumber=34 | EpisodeNumber2=222 | Title=When Love Takes Over | RTitle= Part Two | OriginalAirDate={{start date|2011|2|11}} | AltDate=February 11, 2011 | ProdCode=1034 | ShortSummary= Adam is denial when it becomes obvious that Fiona has a drinking problem and soon has to make a difficult decision regarding her health. Meanwhile, Anya begins to feel guilty when she continues to lie about her age to Dr. Chris. Also, Dave attempts to apologize to Sadie about the comments he made. }} {{Episode list/sublist|Degrassi (season 10) | LineColor=145 | EpisodeNumber=35 | EpisodeNumber2=223 | Title=The Way We Get By | RTitle= Part One | OriginalAirDate={{start date|2011|2|18}} | AltDate=February 18, 2011 | ProdCode=1035 | ShortSummary= Despite helping the basketball team win, Drew finds he is not as popular with the girls as he was last semester, due to what he did with Bianca. Meanwhile, after some hesitation to do something in which Zane is interested, Riley attends an art showing with him. Also, Alli has trouble making friends at her all-girls school. }} {{Episode list/sublist|Degrassi (season 10) | LineColor=145 | EpisodeNumber=36 | EpisodeNumber2=224 | Title=The Way We Get By | RTitle= Part Two | OriginalAirDate={{start date|2011|2|25}} | AltDate=February 25, 2011 | ProdCode=1036 | ShortSummary= Drew attempts to get his friends to accept Bianca, but he soon realizes that she may be as bad as everyone thinks. Meanwhile, Riley does his best to make his mother accept that he's gay. Also, Alli continues to be surprised by Malika's bad girl ways. }} {{Episode list/sublist|Degrassi (season 10) | LineColor=145 | EpisodeNumber=37 | EpisodeNumber2=225 | Title= Jesus, Etc. | RTitle= Part One | OriginalAirDate={{start date|2011|3|4}} | AltDate=March 4, 2011 | ProdCode=1037 | ShortSummary= A newly religious Fitz has been released from juvie and desperately wants to apologize to Clare and Eli, which causes problems in their relationship when Clare thinks Eli has become too controlling. Meanwhile, Sav has to compose an original song to submit to the Music Conservatory and needs a drummer. After choosing Drew, Sav must hide his betrayal from Alli. Also, Jenna wants to focus all of her attention on learning everything she can about babies, and KC isn’t exactly helping things. }} {{Episode list/sublist|Degrassi (season 10) | LineColor=145 | EpisodeNumber=38 | EpisodeNumber2=226 | Title= Jesus, Etc. | RTitle= Part Two | OriginalAirDate={{start date|2011|3|11}} | AltDate=March 11, 2011 | ProdCode=1038 | ShortSummary= Fitz continues to talk to Clare about his newfound faith and sends her numerous emails throughout the night. Clare also begins to see Eli's true colors. Meanwhile, Sav is unsure if Alli's disappearance is part of an attention-seeking stunt or cause for alarm. Also, K.C. and Jenna babysit a six-year-old to test their parenting readiness. }} {{Episode list/sublist|Degrassi (season 10) | LineColor=145 | EpisodeNumber=39 | EpisodeNumber2=227 | Title=Hide and Seek | RTitle= Part One | OriginalAirDate={{start date|2011|3|18}} | AltDate=March 18, 2011 | ProdCode=1039 | ShortSummary= As Holly J. and Chantay prepare to do a work study for a city councilor, Holly J. begins to feel extremely tired and sick and wonders if something is really wrong with her. Meanwhile, Alli is staying at Toronto University with her ex-boyfriend, Johnny, and makes plans to run away to Vancouver. Also, Wesley realizes that he hasn't accomplished anything he set out to do and decides to set a world record in pogo stick jumping. }} {{Episode list/sublist|Degrassi (season 10) | LineColor=145 | EpisodeNumber=40 | EpisodeNumber2=228 | Title=Hide and Seek | RTitle= Part Two | OriginalAirDate={{start date|2011|3|25}} | AltDate=March 25, 2011 | ProdCode=1040 | ShortSummary= Holly J.'s list of symptoms are getting longer and more dangerous as she ignores her friends' pleas to seek help. Meanwhile, Alli tries to leave Toronto but realizes that it will be hard to survive on her own. Also, Wesley makes his attempt to set the Guinness World Record for most Pogo stick jumps in a 24-hour period. }} {{Episode list/sublist|Degrassi (season 10) | LineColor=145 | EpisodeNumber=41 | EpisodeNumber2=229 | Title=Chasing Pavements | RTitle= Part One | OriginalAirDate={{start date|2011|4|1}} | AltDate=April 1, 2011 | ProdCode=1041 | ShortSummary= Fiona has successfully completed inpatient rehab, and she's feeling strong and in control but soon struggles with her sobriety when her court trial against Bobby arrives. Meanwhile, Alli is back at Degrassi, and to keep her mind off Drew, she prepares for a [[Standardized test|standardized]] math exam. Also, Anya gets stuck with Owen for a partner in CPR class and grows uncomfortable with the way he touches her. }} {{Episode list/sublist|Degrassi (season 10) | LineColor=145 | EpisodeNumber=42 | EpisodeNumber2=230 | Title=Chasing Pavements | RTitle= Part Two | OriginalAirDate={{start date|2011|4|8}} | AltDate=April 8, 2011 | ProdCode=1042 | ShortSummary=Fiona questions her feelings for Adam while also beginning to see Holly J. in a different light. Meanwhile, Alli promises the tenth-grade class a school dance if they do well in the math exam and helps everyone study. Also, Anya begins to feel bad for getting Owen kicked out of CPR class. }} {{Episode list/sublist|Degrassi (season 10) | LineColor=145 | EpisodeNumber=43 | EpisodeNumber2=231 | Title=Drop the World | RTitle= Part One | OriginalAirDate={{start date|2011|4|15}} | AltDate=April 15, 2011 | ProdCode=1043 | ShortSummary= Eli is getting increasingly intense about his and Clare's need for togetherness, which begins to creep her out. Meanwhile, Holly J. realizes that she is getting bored with her relationship with Sav and tries to figure out a gentle way to break up with him. Also, Jenna worries that K.C.'s apartment won't be ready for the baby and freaks out after he does not set up the crib when he said he would. }} {{Episode list/sublist|Degrassi (season 10) | LineColor=145 | EpisodeNumber=44 | EpisodeNumber2=232 | Title=Drop the World | RTitle= Part Two | OriginalAirDate={{start date|2011|4|22}} | AltDate=April 22, 2011 | ProdCode=1044 | ShortSummary= Clare grows increasingly scared of Eli and his crazy behavior and demands space between them. In order to win her back, Eli makes a destructive choice that could possibly end his life. Meanwhile, Holly J. tries to redirect Fiona's unrequited love elsewhere but in the process makes things awkward between them. Also, Jenna goes into labor at the dance, while K.C. parties with his friends at his apartment. }} |} ==Reception== ===Ratings=== In Canada, more than one million viewers tuned in to watch the first four episodes.{{cite web |url=http://www.channelcanada.com/Article4853.html |title=Degrassi Wins Timeslot with Key Demo of P12-34 |author=Channel Canada |date=July 16, 2010 |work=BBM Canada |accessdate=August 8, 2010}} ===Accolades=== ''Degrassi'' was nominated for a [[GLAAD Media Award]] in the Best Drama Series category, alongside ''[[Brothers & Sisters (2006 TV series)|Brothers & Sisters]]'', ''[[Grey's Anatomy]]'', ''[[Pretty Little Liars (TV series)|Pretty Little Liars]]'', and the winner ''[[True Blood]]''.{{cite web|title=GLAAD MEDIA AWARDS NOMINEES|url=http://www.glaad.org/mediaawards/22/nominees|accessdate=March 8, 2011|author=Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation}}{{cite web|title=Ricky Martin, Russell Simmons, ‘30 Rock’ among GLAAD Media Award Winners in New York|url=http://glaadblog.org/2011/03/19/ricky-martin-russell-simmons-30-rock-among-glaad-media-award-winners-in-new-york/|accessdate=March 20, 2011|author=Gay & Lesbian Alliance Against Defamation}} These awards, honouring works that fairly and accurately represent the [[LGBT]] community and issues, [[22nd GLAAD Media Awards|were announced]] March 19, 2011. The two-part episode "[[#ep15|My Body Is a Cage]]", centering on transgender character Adam's struggles with his family over his gender identity, won a 2010 [[Peabody Award]] for presenting its subject in a manner that "neither trivializes nor overdramatizes its subject".{{cite web|url=http://www.winnipegfreepress.com/breakingnews/radio-shines-among-2010-peabody-award-winners-others-include-temple-grandin-justified-118992579.html|title='Degrassi' wins prestigious Peabody Award for episodes about transgendered teen|work=The Canadian Press|publisher=Winnipeg Free Press|accessdate=March 31, 2011|author=The Associated Press|date=March 31, 2011}} It also received a nomination for a [[Primetime Emmy Award]] in the outstanding children's program category, alongside ''[[iCarly]]'', ''[[Victorious]]'', ''[[Wizards of Waverly Place]]'', and winner ''A Child's Garden of Poetry''.{{cite web|title=outstanding children's program 2011|url=http://www.emmys.com/nominations/2011/Outstanding%20Children's%20Program|publisher=Academy of Television Arts & Sciences|accessdate=September 12, 2011|date=September 10, 2011}} In the [[2011 Gemini Awards|26th Gemini Awards]], [[Linda Schuyler]], [[Stefan Brogren]], David Lowe, [[Stephen Stohn]], Stephanie Williams, and Brendon Yorke, won an award for best children's or youth fiction program or series, for producing ''Degrassi''. Directors Phil Earnshaw and Pat Williams were nominated for "[[#ep16|My Body Is a Cage (Part 2)]]" and "[[#ep24|All Falls Down (Part 2)]]" respectively, for best direction in a children's or youth program or series, "All Falls Down (Part 2)" would win. "My Body Is a Cage (Part 2)" would win a Gemini for [[Jordan Todosey]] ([[Adam Torres (Degrassi: The Next Generation)|Adam Torres]]) in best performance in a children's or youth program or series, however the writer, Michael Grassi, lost to an episode of ''[[Spliced (TV series)|Spliced]]'', an animated series, for writing in a children's or youth program or series.{{cite web |url=http://www.geminiawards.ca/gemini26/press/GEMINI-Nominees-LIST-News-Release-Aug-3-2011.PDF |title=26th Gemini Awards Nominee List |date=August 3, 2011 |publisher=Gemini Awards |accessdate=August 17, 2011}}{{cite web |url=http://www.geminiawards.ca/gemini26/press/gemini-news-release-aug-31.pdf |title=2011 Gemini Awards Presented in Drama, Children’s or Youth, Comedy and Variety Categories |date=August 31, 2011 |publisher=Gemini Awards |accessdate=September 1, 2011}} At the [[32nd Young Artist Awards|2011 Young Artist Awards]], [[A.J. Saudin]] was nominated as a Recurring Young Actor in the Best Performance in a TV Series.{{cite web |title=32nd Annual Young Artist Awards Nominations |url=http://youngartistawards.org/noms32.html |publisher=[[Young Artist Awards]] |year=2011 |accessdate=February 19, 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150803150806/http://www.youngartistawards.org/noms32.html |archivedate=August 3, 2015 |df=mdy-all }} ==DVD releases== {| border="2" cellpadding="2" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 0 1em 0 0; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse; font-size: 95%;" |- style="background:#EFEFEF" | colspan="5"| '''Season 10, Part 1''' |-valign="top" | rowspan="5" valign="center" align="center" width="180"| [[File:DegrassiSeason10DVD.JPG|140px|Degrassi season 10 Part 1 DVD]] | align="center" width="400" colspan="3"| '''Set details'''{{cite web|title=Degrassi: The Next Generation – Season 10, Part 1 DVD|url=http://www.cduniverse.com/productinfo.asp?PID=8480327|publisher=CD Universe|accessdate=April 27, 2011}} |-valign="top" | colspan="3" align="left" width="400" height="100"| * 24 director's cut episodes * 4-disc set (Canadian release){{cite web |url=http://www.inetvideo.com/Items/N01-0145375 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2011-06-13 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111007040111/http://www.inetvideo.com/Items/N01-0145375 |archivedate=October 7, 2011 |df=mdy-all }} * 2-disc set (American release) * [[Aspect ratio (image)#16:9 standard|1.78:1 aspect ratio]] |- | colspan="3" align="center"| '''Release date'''{{cite web|title=Degrassi: The Next Generation, Season 10 Part 1|url=https://www.amazon.ca/dp/B004R9Q2GG/|publisher=amazon.ca|accessdate=March 30, 2011|year=2011}} |- |align="center"| {{flagicon|Canada}}{{flagicon|USA}} [[DVD region code#Region codes and countries|Region 1]] |- |align="center"| May 17, 2011 |}
{| border="2" cellpadding="2" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 0 1em 0 0; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse; font-size: 95%;" |- style="background:#EFEFEF" | colspan="5"| '''Season 10, Part 2''' |-valign="top" | rowspan="5" valign="center" align="center" width="180"| [[File:DegrassiSeason10p2DVD.JPG|140px|Degrassi season 10 Part 2 DVD]] | align="center" width="400" colspan="3"| '''Set details'''{{cite web|title=Degrassi: The Next Generation, Season 10 Part 2|url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/B005CFC0SS/|publisher=amazon.com|accessdate=September 13, 2011|year=2011}}{{cite web|title=Degrassi: The Next Generation – Package Art and Bonus Items for 'Season 10, Part 2' DVDs|url=http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/news/Degrassi-Generation-Season-10-Part-2/15903|publisher=tvshowsondvd.com|accessdate=September 13, 2011|year=2011|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110926141746/http://www.tvshowsondvd.com/news/Degrassi-Generation-Season-10-Part-2/15903|archivedate=September 26, 2011|df=mdy-all}} |-valign="top" | colspan="3" align="left" width="400" height="100"| * 20 director's cut episodes * 2-disc set * [[Aspect ratio (image)#16:9 standard|1.78:1 aspect ratio]] |- | colspan="3" align="center"| '''Release date'''{{cite web|title=Degrassi: Season 10 Part 2|url=https://www.amazon.ca/dp/B005CFC0SS/|publisher=amazon.ca|accessdate=September 13, 2011|year=2011}} |- |align="center"| {{flagicon|Canada}} [[DVD region code|Canada]] |align="center"| {{flagicon|USA}} [[DVD region code|United States]] |- |align="center"| September 27, 2011 |align="center"| September 13, 2011 |}
{| border="2" cellpadding="2" cellspacing="0" style="margin: 0 1em 0 0; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse; font-size: 95%;" |- style="background:#EFEFEF" | colspan="5"| '''The Complete Season 10''' |-valign="top" | rowspan="5" valign="center" align="center" width="180"| [[File:DegrassiSeason10completeDVD.JPG|140px|Degrassi season 10 DVD]] | align="center" width="400" colspan="3"| '''Set details'''{{cite web|title=Degrassi: The Complete Season 10|url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/B005GRF2QY/|publisher=amazon.com|accessdate=September 13, 2011|year=2011}} |-valign="top" | colspan="3" align="left" width="400" height="100"| * 44 director's cut episodes * 4-disc set * [[Aspect ratio (image)#16:9 standard|1.78:1 aspect ratio]] |- | colspan="3" align="center"| '''Release date'''{{cite web|title=Degrassi: Season 10 Part 1 & 2 |url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/B005GRF2QY/|publisher=amazon.com|accessdate=September 13, 2011|year=2011}} |- |align="center"| {{flagicon|Canada}} [[DVD region code|Canada]] |align="center"| {{flagicon|USA}} [[DVD region code|United States]] |- |align="center"| October 18, 2011 |align="center"| September 13, 2011 |} ==References== {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{Wikipedia books|Seasons of Degrassi: The Next Generation}} * [https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0288937/episodes List of ''Degrassi: The Next Generation'' episodes] at [[Internet Movie Database|IMDb]]. * [http://www.tv.com/degrassi-the-next-generation/show/6810/episode.html?season=10&tag=list_header;paginator;10 Season 10] at [[TV.com]]. {{Degrassi}} {{Use mdy dates|date=July 2012}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Degrassi: The Next Generation (Season 10)}} [[Category:Degrassi: The Next Generation]] [[Category:Transgender in television|Degrassi (Season 10)]] [[Category:2010 Canadian television seasons]] [[Category:2011 Canadian television seasons]]

revision.comment: Rescuing 0 sources and tagging 1 as dead. #IABot (v1.5.1)
revision.text:
'''Digital terrestrial television''' was launched in '''[[Sweden]]''' in 1999. The shutdown of the analogue equivalent started on September 19, 2005, and was finalized on October 15, 2007.{{cite web|url=http://www.sydsvenskan.se/sverige/sista-analoga-tv-natet-slackt/|title=Sista analoga TV-nätet släckt|publisher=Sydsvenskan|language=Swedish|date=15 October 2007|accessdate=18 July 2015}} The network uses the [[DVB-T]]-standard and broadcasts several free-to-air and encrypted channels on a number of multiplexes. The majority of the channels are encrypted and viewing them requires a decoding card. ==History== On April 9, 1997, the [[Riksdag|Swedish Riksdag]] decided that digital terrestrial television (DTT) was to be introduced in Sweden. In June 1998, the government decided which channels were to broadcast in the network. The channels that received a national license were: [[TV3 (Sweden)|TV3]], [[Kanal 5 (Sweden)|Kanal 5]], [[C More Entertainment|Canal+]], Kunskaps-TV i Sverige (to be [[K World]]), [[TV8 (Sweden)|TV8]] and Cell Internet Commerce Development ([[eTV (Sweden)|eTV]]) in addition to [[SVT1]], [[SVT24]] and [[TV4 (Sweden)|TV4]]. Originally, only two multiplexes were planned and therefore [[SVT2]] was omitted. However, before the launch a third multiplex was decided on and SVT2 would be allowed to broadcast. Two companies were created to handle the encryption services, as all channels would be encrypted: [[Senda i Sverige]] who managed the system and decoding cards and [[Boxer TV Access|Boxer]] who rented out set-top-boxes. The digital terrestrial television network was launched on April 1, 1999,{{citation|url=http://www.rtvv.se/_upload/infomatrial/4-861296215106800037407563.pdf |title=En guide till digital-TV |publisher=Swedish Radio and TV Authority |page=11 |year=2000 |isbn=91-973833-2-5 |author=redaktör: Susan Gollenia |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20071020185450/http://www.rtvv.se/_upload/infomatrial/4-861296215106800037407563.pdf |archivedate=2007-10-20 |df= }} making Sweden the second country in Europe to launch digital terrestrial television. It then contained only [[SVT1]], [[SVT2]] and [[SVT24]]. Five regional SVT channels launched some months later. Private companies didn't launch until the autumn when TV3, TV4, Kanal 5, TV8, K World, Canal+ and eTV launched. Canal+ were granted two extra licenses to broadcast Canal+ Gul and Canal+ Blå. Boxer started their business in the autumn. The take-up was slow at first. When the network had been running for six months, only about 500 households had rented the necessary set-top-boxes. New licenses were granted in January 2000. A fourth multiplex was launched in the spring. After this, the DTT network looked like this: *MUX A: [[SVT1]], [[SVT2]], [[SVT24]] and five regional channels. *MUX B: [[TV4 (Sweden)|TV4]], an extra stream from TV4, [[eTV (Sweden)|eTV]] and regional channels (Stockholm 1, NollEttan, DTU7 and Skånekanalen) *MUX C: Canal+, Canal+ Gul, Canal+ Blå, [[Kanal 5 (Sweden)|Kanal 5]], [[K World]] *MUX D: [[TV3 (Sweden)|TV3]], [[ZTV]], [[TV8 (Sweden)|TV8]], [[Viasat Film|TV1000]] and [[Viasat Sport]] MTG said they weren't allowed to use commercial breaks in the terrestrial network. The commercial break were replaced by captions. Kanal 5 did however continue broadcasting their commercial breaks as they did on satellite. In January 2001, MTG introduced an extra fee of 115 SEK for TV3, ZTV and TV8 to cover the losses made as they didn't broadcast advertising. In June 2001, MTG decided to cease their terrestrial broadcasts in August, which they did. As they didn't broadcast anything at all, the license was taken back, making MTG claim that they were thrown out of the DTT network. The five MTG were replaced by other channels during the autumn of 2001: [[Discovery Channel Sweden|Discovery Channel]], [[Animal Planet Nordic|Animal Planet]], [[MTV Nordic]], [[Nickelodeon (Scandinavia)|Nickelodeon]]/[[VH1 Europe|VH1]] and [[Eurosport]]. TV4 were granted a license to broadcast [[CNN International]]. During 2002, both eTV and K World went bankrupt. The SVT regional channels were closed down and replaced by an event channel called [[SVT Extra]]. [[NonStop Television]] started broadcasting a channel called [[Star! Scandinavia|E!]] in the autumn. Senda and Boxer merged on October 1, 2002, to form the new [[Boxer TV Access]]. In December 2002, SVT launched the children's channel [[SVT Barnkanalen|Barnkanalen]] followed in February 2003 by a relaunch of [[SVT24]]. TV4 launched their first major digital channel [[Sjuan|TV4 Plus]], now Sjuan, in March. During 2003 and 2004 the sale of set-top-boxes increased after several years of financial difficulties. The shutdown of the analogue network was decided on in the spring of 2003. In 2004 the launch of a fifth multiplex and more efficient compression made it possible to allow more channels to launch: [[Disney Channel (Scandinavia)|Disney Channel]], [[TV3 (Sweden)|TV3]], [[ZTV]], [[TV4 Film]], [[TV8 (Sweden)|TV8]], [[TCM Nordic|TCM]], [[BBC World]], [[Discovery Travel & Living Europe|Discovery Travel & Adventure]] and [[Showtime Scandinavia|Showtime]]. This meant that MTG returned to the DTT network. They did broadcast free-to-air for some months, but in August they decided to scramble their broadcasts. 2004 also saw the launch of [[Kunskapskanalen]] from SVT and [[Utbildningsradion|UR]]. At the end of 2004, the DTT networked looked like this: *MUX 1: [[SVT1]], [[SVT2]], [[SVT24]], [[SVT Barnkanalen|Barnkanalen]]/[[Kunskapskanalen]] (and [[SVT Extra]]) *MUX 2: [[TV4 (Sweden)|TV4]], [[Sjuan|TV4 Plus]], [[Med i tv]], [[TV4 Film]], [[CNN International]] and regional channels. *MUX 3: Canal+, Canal+ Film 1, Canal+ Film 2 Weekend Sport, [[Kanal 5 (Sweden)|Kanal 5]], [[TV3 (Sweden)|TV3]] and [[Disney Channel (Scandinavia)|Disney Channel]]/[[Canal 7 (Sweden)|Canal 7]] *MUX 4: [[Discovery Channel Sweden|Discovery Channel]], [[Animal Planet Nordic|Animal Planet]], [[MTV Nordic]], [[Nickelodeon (Scandinavia)|Nickelodeon]]/[[VH1 Europe|VH1]], [[Eurosport]], [[Star! Scandinavia|Star!]] and [[ZTV]] *MUX 5: [[Discovery Travel & Living Europe|Discovery Travel & Living]], [[TCM Nordic|TCM]], [[BBC World]], [[Showtime Scandinavia|Showtime]] and [[TV8 (Sweden)|TV8]]. In early 2005, TV8 was moved to MUX 3 which had higher coverage than MUX 5, which at start only covered 50 percent of the households. Several changes were made to the local programmes during 2005. TV4 started making their local stations available in the digital network (previously [[TV4 Stockholm]] was shown nationwide) and SVT started providing an alternative local output so the viewer could choose to watch a neighbouring region. New regional commercial channels started: [[ByTV Jämtland]] in [[Jämtland]] and [[Kanal Lokal]] in [[Stockholm]], [[Gothenburg]] and [[Skåne]]. On September 19, 2005, the island of [[Gotland]] became the first region to have its analogue transmitters turned off. This continued during the autumn when the Gävle and Motala transmitters were shut down. The fact that only the SVT channels, TV4 and the local channels were available [[free-to-air]] was a problem during the switch-off as those affected didn't feel they got enough in return for the trouble of having to buy set-top-boxes and in some cases a new antenna. When new licenses for 2006 were pending, the Minister of Education and Culture [[Leif Pagrotsky]] stated that those broadcasters who were going to broadcast free-to-air would be more likely to receive a new license. New licenses were awarded in February 2006. This meant that: * [[Viasat]] would be awarded a license to broadcast [[TV6 (Sweden)|TV6]] round-the-clock in MUX 2 * The newspaper [[Aftonbladet]] and [[Axel and Margaret Ax:son Johnson Foundation]] would share free-to-air one stream in MUX5. Aftonbladet would broadcast what became [[Aftonbladet TV7]] on Weekdays while [[Axess TV]] was broadcast in the weekend. * [[SBS Broadcasting]] received one stream in MUX 4 that would be shared by [[The Voice TV Sweden|The Voice TV]] and a channel called "C 5". The Voice TV would broadcast free-to-air from 6 a.m to 6 p.m. while "C 5", renamed [[ONE Television]] at launch, would broadcast 6 p.m. to 6 a.m. * [[NonStop Television]] had to replace [[Showtime Scandinavia|Showtime]] with a new channel called "NonStop Filmfestival". It launched in May as [[Silver (TV channel)|Silver]]. * [[BBC Prime]] would broadcast one pay channel in MUX 5. * [[Star! Scandinavia|Star!]] got its hours cut and would now broadcast in the Nickelodeon downtime from 6 p.m. to 6 a.m. * [[VH1 Europe|VH1]], which was previously broadcast in the Nickelodeon downtime, would now broadcast "if space was available". Initially it did broadcast round-the-clock, but when this space was taken over by The Voice/ONE the channel disappeared. VH1 returned in June 2006, broadcasting overnight on the MTV's space. In June 2006, SVT and TV4 did broadcast the [[2006 FIFA World Cup]] in [[High-definition television|high-definition]] on temporary frequencies from a few transmitters. Those frequencies were taken back when the World Cup ended. In December 2006, the new right-wing government decided that a sixth multiplex would be taken into regular use, initially only to secure that the broadcasts of [[TV Finland]] would be secured when the transmitter of the capital region was turned off. The Boxer monopoly on pay television was criticized by the [[European Commission]] and on October 17, 2006, it announced would be taking Sweden to the [[European Court of Justice]] as the country had failed to abolish the monopoly. SBS Broadcasting decided to replace [[ONE Television]] with a new channel called [[Kanal 9]] in February 2007. With the launch of Kanal 9, they were allowed to adjust the Kanal 9/The Voice TV timeshare. On May 26, 2007, [[SVT HD]] was launched on the remaining capacity of the multiplex that broadcast TV Finland, broadcasting HDTV programmes from four transmitters around the capital using MPEG-4 AVC compression. On March 27, 2008, new broadcasts licenses were announced by the [[Swedish Radio and TV Authority|Radio and TV Authority]] (RTVV). This was the first time that the RTVV issued broadcast licenses and not government. New channels granted national licenses were [[Comedy Central Sweden|Comedy Central]], [[Discovery Science Europe|Discovery Science]], [[Jetix]], [[National Geographic Channel Scandinavia|National Geographic Channel]], [[Showtime Scandinavia|Showtime]], [[TV4 Sport]], [[Viasat Film|TV1000]] and [[Viasat Sport 1]]. In addition, new regional licenses were given to [[24nt]], [[24 Västra Götaland]], [[Borås Tidning TV]], [[Kanal 12]] and [[ST TV]] as well as [[Kanal Lokal]] in Dalarna, Gävleborg, Jämtland, Norrbotten, Västernorrland, Småland and Blekinge. Out of the new channels, Discovery Science, National Geographic Channel, Showtime, Jetix, TV1000 and Viasat Sport 1 would be put in the new sixth national multiplex. I addition, [[BBC World]] and [[Discovery Travel & Living Europe|Discovery Travel & Living]] would move to this multiplex. The new multiplex would use the newer [[H.264/MPEG-4 AVC]] compression which would allow ten channels to broadcast from one network simultaneously, as opposed to the older, less efficient, [[MPEG-2]] used by the existing multiplexes. Some channels got new broadcasting hours. [[Axess TV]] could start broadcasting the entire week, [[Aftonbladet TV7]] and [[Canal 7 (Sweden)|Canal 7]] would timeshare so TV7 broadcast during the daytime and Canal 7 during the evening and night, [[VH1 Europe|VH1]] got to broadcast between 10 p.m. and 6 a.m., [[Nickelodeon (Scandinavia)|Nickelodeon]] had its hours extended, reducing those of [[Star! Scandinavia|Star!]]. The new licenses also stipulated that TV7, [[The Voice TV Sweden|The Voice TV]] and Star! would have to move to the sixth multiplex on January 1, 2009. This makes TV7, Canal 7, [[Kanal 9]], The Voice TV and Star! to become 24-hour channels and also provides the space where Comedy Central will broadcast.[http://www.rtvv.se/_upload/Nyheter/pdf/Tillst%E5nd%20att%20s%E4nda%20TV-program.pdf Tillstånd att sända TV-program]{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Radio and TV Authority, March 27, 2008 As of 2010 the following line up is as follow: *MUX 1: [[SVT1]], [[SVT2]], [[Kunskapskanalen|SVTK]], [[SVTB]], [[SVT24]], [[SR P1]], [[SR P2]] Music and [[SR P3]] *MUX 2: [[TV4 (Sweden)|TV4]], [[Sjuan]], [[TV4 Fakta]], [[TV4 Film]], [[TV6 (Sweden)|TV6]], [[CNN International|CNN]] and [[TV400]] *MUX 3: [[C More Entertainment|Canal+ First]], [[C More Entertainment|Canal+ Hits Sport Weekend]], [[C More Entertainment|Canal+ Sport 1]], [[Disney Channel]], [[Kanal 5 (Sweden)|Kanal 5]], [[SF-kanalen]], [[TV3 (Sweden)|TV3]], [[TV8 (Sweden)|TV8]] and [[VH1]] *MUX 4: [[Animal Planet]], [[Comedy Central]], [[Discovery Channel]], [[Eurosport]], [[Kanal 9]], [[MTV Sweden]], [[Nickelodeon (TV channel)|Nickelodeon]] and [[ZTV]] *MUX 5: [[Axess TV]], [[BBC World]], [[Canal 7 (Sweden)|Canal 7]], [[Discovery Science]], [[Discovery Travel & Living]], [[Disney XD]], [[Showtime Scandinavia|Showtime]], [[Star!]], [[TV7 (Sweden)|7]], [[Silver (TV channel)|Silver]], [[Turner Classic Movies|TCM]], [[TV4 Sport]], [[24nt]]/[[24Corren]]/[[24Norrbotten]]/[[Kanal 12]] and [[TV Finland]] *MUX 6: [[C More Entertainment|Canal+ Sport HD]], [[Discovery HD Showcase]], [[Eurosport HD]], [[Kanal 5 (Sweden)|Kanal 5 HD]] and [[Silver HD]] *MUX 7: [[SVT1|SVT1 HD]], [[SVT2|SVT2 HD]] and [[TV4 HD (Sweden)|TV4 HD]] ==Channels== As of May 2016: {| class="sortable wikitable" |- !LCN

{{Infobox UK transmitter |name = Droitwich |image = [[Image:Droitwichtransmitter.jpg|250px]] |caption = Masts at the Droitwich transmitting station |map_name = Worcestershire |location = [[Droitwich]], [[Worcestershire]] |height = {{convert|213.36|m|ft|0}} |height2 = |gridref = SO929663 |built = 1934 |demolished = |collapsed = }} The '''Droitwich transmitting station''' is a large broadcasting facility for [[longwave|long-wave]] and [[mediumwave|medium-wave]] transmissions, established in 1934 in the [[civil parishes in England|civil parish]] of [[Dodderhill]], just outside the village of [[Wychbold]], near [[Droitwich]] in [[Worcestershire]], [[England]] ({{gbmapping|SO929663}}). The site is the location of the [[BBC|British Broadcasting Corporation]]'s most powerful long-wave transmitter, which together with the two Scottish long-wave transmitters at [[Burghead transmitting station|Burghead]] and [[Westerglen transmitting station|Westerglen]] forms a [[Single frequency network|network broadcasting on the same frequency]]. The masts can be seen to the east from the [[M5 motorway]], between Droitwich and [[Bromsgrove]], as well as to the west from the Herefordshire/Worcestershire border. At night, the two sets of [[aircraft warning lights]] are visible from a long distance. Due to the bright red lights illuminated at night, some locals have renamed the site "the devil horns of Wychbold". The station is owned and operated by [[Arqiva]].
==Technical specifications== The long-wave frequency used was 200 kilohertz (frequently referred to by the wavelength, 1,500 metres) until 1 February 1988<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.bbceng.info/Operations/transmitter_ops/Reminiscences/Droitwich/droitwich_calling.htm | title = BBCEng.Info - Droitwich Calling | accessdate = 31 January 2012 | work= }}</ref> when it was changed to 198 kilohertz, and the power is currently 500 kilowatts. The carrier frequency is controlled by a [[rubidium]] [[atomic clock|atomic frequency standard]] in the transmitter building, enabling the transmission to be used as an [[radio clock|off-air frequency standard]]. For long-wave, a [[T-aerial]] is used, which is suspended between two {{convert|213|m|ft|-high|adj=mid|sigfig=2}} guyed steel lattice [[radio masts and towers|radio masts]], which stand {{convert|180|m|ft|sigfig=2}} apart from each other. There are also two guyed [[mast radiator]]s at the site, which are used for transmitting AM medium-wave radio programmes on 693 kilohertz, 1053 kilohertz and 1215 kilohertz.
==Transmissions== [[BBC Radio 4 Longwave]] is transmitted on 198 kHz. This signal also carries radio data encoded using [[phase modulation]], giving a time-of-day signal, and [[radio teleswitch]] control signals for [[Economy 7]] electric-heating systems.
[[BBC Radio 5 Live]] is broadcast on 693 kHz medium wave (MW), providing coverage for most of the [[Midlands (England)|English Midlands]] and [[Wales]] at a signal strength (150 kW) which is one of the strongest for that station, equal to [[Brookmans Park Transmitter|Brookmans Park]] and second only to [[Moorside Edge Transmitter|Moorside Edge]].
During [[World War II]] coded messages, read during normal programme broadcasts, were sent to the [[French Resistance]] using the transmitter.<ref>[http://www.bbc.co.uk/herefordandworcester/content/articles/2005/10/21/droitwich_transmitter_feature.shtml BBC Feature] Retrieved 29 July 2009</ref>
In 2011 as part of the [[BBC]] cuts it was announced that there would be no re-investment in [[longwave|long wave]] which may mean an eventual end to [[BBC Radio 4]] in this part of the [[radio spectrum]].<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/entertainment-arts-15165926 BBC set to cut 2,000 jobs by 2017]</ref> ''The Guardian'' published a story in October 2011 saying that the transmitter relies upon a pair of glass valves, of which there are fewer than 10 left in the world, and the BBC did not believe it was safe enough to manufacture more.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/media/2011/oct/09/bbc-radio4-long-wave-goodbye Radio 4's long wave goodbye]</ref>
==Reception== The [[BBC Radio 4|Radio 4]] LW signal from Droitwich covers most of England and Wales. There are supplementary long-wave transmitters in Scotland (Burghead and Westerglen, both 50 kW), with medium-wave transmitters in various parts of England, Scotland and Northern Ireland. The station can also be heard clearly in most of the Republic of Ireland, particularly along eastern and southern counties. Reception is also possible in Western Europe, including Italy.
==Services available== {| class="wikitable sortable" !Frequency !kW !Service |- |198 [[kHz]] |500 |[[BBC Radio 4]] |- |693 kHz |150 |[[BBC Radio 5 Live]] |- |1053 kHz |500 |[[Talksport]] |- |1215 kHz |105 |[[Absolute Radio]] |}
==See also== * [[List of masts]] * [[List of radio stations in the United Kingdom]] * [[List of tallest buildings and structures in Great Britain]] * [[Radio teleswitch]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== * [http://tx.mb21.co.uk/gallery/droitwich/ The Transmission Gallery: Droitwich Transmitter photographs and information] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20070927150502/http://www.energynetworks.org/rts/ Radio Teleswitch Services] * [http://www.radiorewind.co.uk/radio1/droitwich.htm Radio Rewind Droitwich Page] * [http://downloads.bbc.co.uk/rd/pubs/reports/1984-19.pdf Specification of BBC phase-modulated transmissions on long-wave] * [http://www.bbceng.info/Operations/transmitter_ops/Reminiscences/Droitwich/droitwich_calling2.pdf Station History] * [https://player.bfi.org.uk/free/film/watch-bbc-droitwich-1935-online Droitwich The World's Most Modern Long Wave Transmitter]
{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2011}}

{{Unreferenced|date=May 2008}} An '''editor's cut''' of a [[motion picture]] is made by the [[film editor]] on their own, or working with the [[film director]]. The editor tapes together the first cut of the film, the "editor's cut", arranging the separate takes into a coherent story according to the plan communicated by the director. The editor's version of the film will often be as much as two hours beyond the final running time of the film. Working from the editor's cut, decisions then need to be made, usually together with other creative staff, to improve continuity, balance the story, trim or delete scenes, etc.
A version supposedly nearer to the director's original creative vision is sometimes marketed as a ''[[director's cut]]''. These special-market versions of a movie [[DVD]] are more expensive than the regular edition, as they are usually longer than the theatre version, and have extra discs often including "making of ... " documentaries, out-take collections, extended interviews with cast and crew, etc.
== See also == * [[Working cut]]
[[Category:Film and video terminology]]
{{film-term-stub}}
