revision.comment: /* Intersport groundshares */clean up, replaced: [[Doncaster R.L.C.| → [[Doncaster R.L.F.C.| using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
{{more citations needed|date=November 2007}} '''Groundshare''' is the principle of sharing a stadium between two local sport teams. This is usually done for the purpose of reducing the costs of either construction of two separate facilities and related maintenance.<ref name="main">[http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/sport/football/premier_league/tottenham/article2821147.ece Main Article]-Main Article</ref>
==Types of groundshare==
===Intersport Groundshares=== Given sufficient compatibility between facility requirements, two teams that do not play the same sport may share a ground or a stadium. North American indoor arenas commonly feature [[basketball]] and [[ice hockey]] teams sharing the facility during their common fall-to-spring season; a layer of insulation and a basketball floor can easily be laid over or removed from the hockey rink, and dasherboards disassembled or reconfigured, in a matter of hours. Historically [[baseball]] and [[American football]] teams often shared a large general-purpose outdoor or domed stadium, particularly during the [[multi-purpose stadium]] era of the 1960s-1990s, despite the dissimilarity of their fields.<ref name="main" /> This practice fell out of fashion in the 1990s as baseball teams constructed highly specialized stadia in which football fields fit awkwardly if at all. Football teams in turn built more specifically rectangular stadia, often with a floor slightly wider than American football requirements to comfortably accommodate domestic or international soccer as American spectator interest in that sport grew.
A variation on the groundshare concept exists commonly within the [[NBA]] and the [[NHL]]. As the requirements for a regulation NHL hockey rink and a regulation NBA basketball court do not differ significantly, in the majority of cases where a metropolitan area has both an NBA and an NHL franchise, the teams share the same arena.
===Intrasport Groundshares=== This is two teams that play the same sport share the same ground. These may be two non-competing teams who play at different levels, such as [[Bury F.C.]], renting [[Gigg Lane]] to [[F.C. United of Manchester]] in [[England]].<ref name="main" />
===Intraleague Groundshare=== This is where two teams in the same league share the same ground, such as the [[New York Giants]] and [[New York Jets]] sharing [[MetLife Stadium]].
In the American [[NBA]], only two franchises share one arena: both the [[Los Angeles Lakers]] and the [[Los Angeles Clippers]] share [[Staples Center]].
==Examples of groundsharing==
===Intraleague groundshares===
*[[Ajinomoto Stadium]]: [[FC Tokyo]] and [[Tokyo Verdy 1969]] *[[Allianz Arena]]: [[Bayern Munich|Bayern München]] and [[TSV 1860 München]] *[[Azadi Stadium]]: [[Persepolis F.C.]] and [[Esteghlal F.C.]] *[[Estádio Algarve]]: [[S.C. Farense]] and [[Louletano D.C.]] *[[Estádio do Maracanã]]: [[Botafogo de Futebol e Regatas|Botafogo FR]], [[Clube de Regatas do Flamengo|CR Flamengo]] and [[Fluminense Football Club|Fluminense FC]] *[[Jan Breydel Stadium]]: [[Club Brugge K.V.]] and [[Cercle Brugge K.S.V.]] *[[Letzigrund]]: [[FC Zürich]] currently share their home stadium with [[Grasshopper Club Zürich]] until the completion of Grasshopper Zurich's new stadium. *[[Kadir Has Stadium]]: [[Kayserispor]] and [[Kayseri Erciyesspor]] *[[MetLife Stadium]]: [[New York Giants]] and [[New York Jets]] *[[Philip II Arena]]: [[FK Vardar]] and [[FK Rabotnički]] *[[Stadio Atleti Azzurri d'Italia]] : [[Atalanta B.C.]] and [[U.C. Albinoleffe]] *[[Stadio Giuseppe Meazza]] ("San Siro"): [[AC Milan]] and [[Internazionale Milano F.C.|Inter Milan]] *[[Stadio Luigi Ferraris]]: [[U.C. Sampdoria]] and [[Genoa C.F.C.]] *[[Stadio Marc'Antonio Bentegodi]]: [[A.C. Chievo Verona]] and [[Hellas Verona F.C.]] *[[Stadio Olimpico]]: [[A.S. Roma]] and [[S.S. Lazio]] *[[Staples Center]]: [[Los Angeles Lakers]] and [[Los Angeles Clippers]] *[[Tele2 Arena]]: [[Djurgårdens IF Fotboll]] and [[Hammarby Fotboll]] *[[Teddy Stadium]]: [[Beitar Jerusalem F.C.]] and [[Hapoel Jerusalem F.C.]] *[[Tokyo Dome]]: [[Yomiuri Giants]] and [[Hokkaido Nippon Ham Fighters]] (until 2004) *[[Gamla Ullevi]]: [[IFK Göteborg]], [[GAIS]], [[Örgryte IS]] * Queensgate Stadium (England) : [[Bridlington Town F.C.|Bridlington Town]] and [[Scarborough Athletic F.C.|Scarborough Athletic]] * Heritage Park: [[Bishop Auckland F.C.|Bishop Auckland]] and [[Darlington 1883|Darlington]] * [[Stade Charlety]] : [[Paris FC]] and [[Paris Saint-Germain Féminines]] * [[Salt Lake Stadium]]: [[East Bengal FC]] and [[Mohun Bagan AC]]
====Former====
*[[Boleyn Ground]]: [[West Ham United F.C.]] shared their home stadium with [[Charlton Athletic F.C.]] from 1991 until 1992. *[[Estadio Jalisco]]: [[Futbol Club Atlas]] and [[Guadalajara]] until Guadalajara moved to their new home of [[Estadio OmniLife]] in 2010. *[[Halton Stadium]]: [[Widnes Vikings]] shared their home stadium with [[St Helens R.F.C.]] in 2011. *[[Maine Road]]: [[Manchester City F.C.]] shared their home stadium with [[Manchester United F.C.]] from 1945 until 1949. *[[Moss Rose]]: [[Macclesfield Town F.C.]] shared their home stadium with [[Chester City F.C.]] from 1990 until 1992. *[[Olympic Stadium (Munich)|Munich Olympic Stadium]]: [[Bayern Munich|Bayern München]] and [[TSV 1860 München]] shared this stadium from 1972 until 2005. *[[Priestfield Stadium]]: [[Gillingham F.C.]] shared their home stadium with [[Brighton & Hove Albion F.C.]] from 1997 until 1999. *[[Selhurst Park]]: [[Crystal Palace F.C.]] shared their home stadium with [[Charlton Athletic F.C.]] from 1985 until 1991 and latterly [[Wimbledon F.C.]] from 1991 until 2003. *[[Stadio delle Alpi]]: [[Juventus]] and [[Torino F.C.|Torino]] shared this stadium from 1990 until 2006. *[[Stadio Olimpico di Torino]]: [[Juventus]] and [[Torino F.C.|Torino]] shared this stadium from 1958 until 1990 and latterly from 2006 until 2011. *[[StubHub Center]]: [[Los Angeles Galaxy]] and [[Club Deportivo Chivas USA|CD Chivas USA]] from 2005 until Chivas USA folded in 2013 *[[Twerton Park]]: [[Bath City F.C.]] shared their home stadium with [[Bristol Rovers F.C.]] from 1986 until 1996 and latterly [[Team Bath F.C.]] from 1999 until 2009. *[[Ullevaal Stadion]]: [[Vålerenga Fotball|Vålerenga]], [[Lyn Fotball|Lyn]] until 2009 *[[Watling Street (Dartford)|Watling Street]]: [[Dartford F.C.]] shared their home stadium with [[Maidstone United F.C. (1897)|Maidstone United F.C.]] from 1988 until 1992. * [[Parc des Princes]] : [[Paris Saint-Germain]] and [[Racing Paris]] between 1982 and 1989
===Intersport groundshares=== *[[Adams Park]]: [[Wycombe Wanderers F.C.]] (football) share their home stadium with [[Wasps RFC|London Wasps]] (rugby union) from 2002. *[[Ashton Gate Stadium|Ashton Gate]]: [[Bristol City F.C.|Bristol City FC]] and [[Bristol Rugby]]. *[[BC Place]]: [[BC Lions]] (Canadian football) and [[Vancouver Whitecaps FC]] (association football) *[[Blackwell Meadows]]: [[Darlington RFC]] and [[Darlington Football Club|Darlington F.C.]] *[[Bramall Lane]]: [[Sheffield United F.C.]] (football) share their home stadium with [[Sheffield Eagles]] (rugby league). *[[CenturyLink Field]]: [[Seattle Seahawks]] (American football) and [[Seattle Sounders FC]] (football) *[[DW Stadium]]: [[Wigan Athletic F.C.]] (football) and [[Wigan Warriors]] (rugby league) *[[Headingley Stadium#Rugby ground|Headingley]] [[Headingley Rugby Stadium|Rugby Stadium]]: [[Leeds Rhinos]] (rugby league) share their home stadium with [[Yorkshire Carnegie]] (rugby union). In addition [[Yorkshire County Cricket Club]] (cricket) are based in an adjacent stadium. *[[Home's Stadium Kobe]]: [[Vissel Kobe]] (football) and [[Kobelco Steelers]] (rugby union) *[[Gateshead International Stadium]]: [[Gateshead F.C.|Gateshead]] (football) and [[Newcastle Thunder|Gateshead Thunder]] (Rugby League) *[[John Smith's Stadium]]: [[Huddersfield Town A.F.C.]] ([[football (soccer)|football]]) and [[Huddersfield Giants]] ([[rugby league]]). *[[KC Stadium]]: [[Hull City A.F.C.]] (football) and [[Hull F.C.]] (rugby league) *[[Keepmoat Stadium]]: [[Doncaster Rovers F.C.]] (football) share their stadium with [[Doncaster R.L.F.C.|Doncaster]] (rugby league). *[[Liberty Stadium]]: [[Swansea City A.F.C.]] (football) and [[Ospreys (rugby union)|Ospreys]] (rugby union) *[[Madejski Stadium]]: [[Reading F.C.]] (football) share their home stadium with [[London Irish]] (rugby union). *[[Meadow Lane]]: [[Notts County F.C.]] (football) share their home stadium with [[Nottingham R.F.C.]] (rugby union). *[[Oakland Alameda Coliseum]]: [[Oakland Athletics]] (baseball) and [[Oakland Raiders]] (American football) *[[Racecourse Ground]]: [[Wrexham A.F.C.]] (football) share their home stadium with [[North Wales Crusaders]] (rugby league). *[[Salford City Stadium]]: [[Salford Red Devils|Salford City Reds]] (rugby league) share their home stadium with [[Sale Sharks]] (rugby union). *[[Sapporo Dome]]: [[Hokkaido Nippon Ham Fighters]] ([[baseball]]) and [[Consadole Sapporo]] (football) *[[Spotland Stadium]]: [[Rochdale A.F.C.]] (football) share their home stadium with [[Rochdale Hornets]] (rugby league) *[[StubHub Center]]: [[Los Angeles Galaxy]] (football) share their home temporarily with the [[Los Angeles Chargers]] (American football) *[[Suncorp Stadium]]: [[Brisbane Broncos]] (rugby league), [[Queensland Roar]] (football) and [[Queensland Reds]] (rugby union) *[[The Shay]]: [[F.C. Halifax Town]] (football) share their home stadium with [[Halifax R.L.F.C.|Halifax]] (rugby league). *[[Twickenham Stoop]]: [[Harlequin F.C.]] (rugby union) share their home stadium with [[London Broncos]] aka Harlequins RL (rugby league) from 1997 until 1999 and latterly from 2006. *[[Yamaha Stadium]]: [[Júbilo Iwata]] (football) and [[Yamaha Júbilo]] (rugby union) *[[Yankee Stadium]]: [[New York Yankees]] (baseball) and [[New York City FC]] (soccer) *[[Stade Jean Bouin]]: [[Red Star FC]] (football association) and [[Stade Français Paris]] (rugby union)
====Former==== *[[Angel Stadium|Anaheim Stadium]] (now Angel Stadium of Anaheim): [[Los Angeles Angels|California Angels]] (baseball; now Los Angeles Angels) shared with [[Los Angeles Rams]] (American football) from 1980–1994 *[[Boundary Park]]: [[Oldham Athletic A.F.C.]] (football) shared their home stadium with [[Oldham R.L.F.C.]] (rugby league) from 1997 until 2001 and latterly from 2003 until 2009. *[[Bramall Lane]]: [[Yorkshire County Cricket Club]] (cricket) shared the stadium with [[Sheffield FC]] (football) from 1862 until 1875, [[Sheffield Wednesday F.C.]] (football) from 1868 until 1888 and [[Sheffield United F.C.]] (football) from 1889 until 1975. *[[Busch Memorial Stadium]]: [[St. Louis Cardinals]] (baseball) shared with [[History of the St. Louis Cardinals (NFL)|St. Louis Cardinals]] (American football) from 1966–1987 and [[St. Louis Rams]] (American football) in 2005 *[[Cardiff City Stadium]]: [[Cardiff City F.C.]] (football) and [[Cardiff Blues]] (rugby union) from 2009 until 2012. *[[Deepdale]]: [[Preston North End F.C.]] (football) shared their home stadium with [[Chorley Lynx|Lancashire Lynx]] (rugby league) from 1996 until 2000. *[[Craven Cottage]]: [[Fulham F.C.]] (football) shared their home stadium with [[London Broncos|Fulham RLFC]] (rugby league) from 1980 until 1984. *[[Don Valley Stadium]]: [[Rotherham United F.C.]] (football) shared with [[Sheffield Eagles]] (rugby league) in this predmoninately athletics stadium in 2008 and latterly from 2011 until 2012. *[[Edgeley Park]]: [[Stockport County F.C.]] (football) shared their home stadium with [[Sale Sharks]] (rugby union) from 2003 until 2012, when Sale moved to the [[Salford City Stadium]]. *[[Elland Road]]: [[Leeds United F.C.]] (football) shared their home stadium with [[Hunslet R.L.F.C.|Hunslet]] (rugby league from the mid-1980s until 1995. *[[Giants Stadium]]: New York Giants and New York Jets (American football) and [[New York Red Bulls]] (association football) until its demolition in 2009. *[[Griffin Park]]: [[Brentford F.C.]] (football) shared their home stadium with [[London Broncos]] (rugby league) from 2002 until 2006. *[[Hubert H. Humphrey Metrodome]]: [[Minnesota Twins]] (baseball until 2009), [[Minnesota Vikings]] ([[American football]] - [[NFL]]), [[University of Minnesota]] Golden Gophers (American football - [[NCAA]] under 2009) *[[Kingdome]]: [[Seattle Seahawks]] (American football) shared with [[Seattle Sounders (1974–83)|Seattle Sounders]] (association football) from 1976–1983, [[Seattle Mariners]] (baseball) from 1977–1999, and [[Seattle SuperSonics]] (basketball) from 1978–1985 *[[Kingston Park (stadium)|Kingston Park]]: [[Newcastle Falcons]] (rugby union), [[Newcastle Blue Star]] (now defunct) (football) until 2009. *[[Loftus Road]]: [[Queens Park Rangers F.C.]] (football) shared their home stadium with [[Wasps RFC|London Wasps]] (rugby union) from 1996 until 2002 and latterly with [[Fulham F.C.]] (football) from 2002 until 2004. *[[Madejski Stadium]]: [[Reading F.C.]] shared their home stadium with [[Richmond F.C.]] (rugby union) from 1998 until 1999. *[[Memorial Stadium (Bristol)]]: [[Bristol Rovers]] (football) and [[Bristol Rugby]] (rugby union) from 1996 until 2014 *[[Odsal Stadium]]: [[Bradford Bulls|Bradford Northern RLFC]] (rugby league) shared their home stadium with [[Bradford City A.F.C.]] (football) from 1985 until 1986. *[[Robert F. Kennedy Memorial Stadium|RFK Stadium]]: [[Washington Redskins]] (football) shared with [[Washington Senators (1961-1971)|the second Washington Senators]] baseball from 1962-1971 and various [[North American Soccer League (1968-84)|NASL]] soccer clubs intermittently from 1968-1984, then [[D.C. United]] soccer in 1996; United then shared with the [[Washington Nationals]] from 2005-07. *[[Rogers Centre]] (formerly SkyDome): [[Toronto Blue Jays]] (baseball) shared with [[Toronto Argonauts]] (Canadian football) from 1989–2015 and [[Toronto Raptors]] (basketball) from 1995–1999 *[[Sixfields Stadium]]: [[Northampton Town F.C.]] currently share their home stadium with [[Coventry City F.C.]]. *[[The Shay]]: [[Halifax Town A.F.C.]] (football) from 1998 until 2008 shared their home with [[Halifax R.L.F.C.|Halifax]] (rugby league). *[[The Valley (London)|The Valley]]: [[Charlton Athletic F.C.]] (football) shared their home stadium with [[London Broncos]] (rugby league) from 1996 to 1997 and latterly from 1999 to 2000. *[[Valley Parade]]: [[Bradford City A.F.C.]] (football) shared their home stadium with [[Bradford Park Avenue A.F.C.]] (football) from 1973 until 1974 and latterly [[Bradford Bulls]] (rugby league) from 2001 until 2002. *[[Vicarage Road]]: [[Watford F.C.]] (football) shared their home stadium with [[Wealdstone F.C.]] from 1991 until 1994 and latterly [[Saracens F.C.]] from 1997 until 2013.
==References== {{reflist}} * [http://www.rugbynetwork.net/main/s344/st122777.htm Additional Source]
[[Category:Sports venues]]

'''Guardian''', in '''comics''', may refer to:
* [[Guardian (DC Comics)]], the alias of Jim Harper, a costumed hero * [[Guardian (Marvel Comics)]], the alias of James Hudson, a superhero * Guardian, the alias of Heather Hudson, wife of James Hudson, better known as [[Vindicator (comics)|Vindicator]] * ''Guardians'', a Marvel Comics series<ref>{{comicbookdb|type=title|id=4821|title=''Guardians''}}</ref>
It may also refer to: * [[Guardian angel (comics)]], the superhero alias of Hop Harrigan * [[Guardians of the Galaxy (disambiguation)|Guardians of the Galaxy]], two Marvel Comics teams ** [[Guardians of the Galaxy (1969 team)]] ** [[Guardians of the Galaxy (2008 team)]] * [[Guardians of the Universe]], DC Comics aliens who are behind the Green Lantern Corps * [[New Guardians]], a DC Comics team picked by the Guardians of the Universe * [[Global Guardians]], a DC Comics superhero team * [[Guardian (Mal Duncan)]], also known as Vox, Hornblower, and the Herald, a DC Comics superhero
==See also== * [[Guardian (disambiguation)]]
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.comment: Fix [[:Category:CS1 maint: Extra text|CS1 cite error]] (extra text in "page" or "edition" parameter), and genfixes using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text:
[[File:FranckIILouise.jpg|thumb|240px|French hip-hop [[dance company]] Franck II Louise performing at [[Breakin' Convention]] 2006.]] '''Hip-hop theater''' is a form of theater that presents contemporary stories through the use of one or more of the four elements of hip-hop culture—[[b-boying]], [[Graffiti#Modern graffiti|graffiti]] writing, [[rapping|MCing]] (rapping), and [[Turntablism|DJing]].<ref>{{cite podcast | url = https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=4183762 | title = Will Power, Telling Stories through 'Hip Hop Theatre' | website = [[NPR]] | publisher = The Tavis Smiley Show | host = Tavis Smiley | date = November 23, 2004 | accessdate = October 2, 2011}}</ref><ref name=mania>{{cite news|last=Hopkins |first=Philip |title=Hip-Hop Takes the Stage |work=Theater Mania |date=June 3, 2003 |url=http://www.theatermania.com/content/news.cfm?int_news_id=3579 |accessdate=November 3, 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/628apiFhB?url=http://www.theatermania.com/content/news.cfm?int_news_id=3579 |archivedate=October 2, 2011 |quote='Everyone has a different definition of how hip-hop applies to theater,' says Valentin, who published the hip-hop-culture-focused Stress Magazine before becoming involved as a producer with some of the genre's bigger names. According to Valentin, 'Every show doesn't necessarily have to include the four basic elements of hip-hop: a DJ, graffiti-based visual art, breakdancing, and an MC or rapper.' But he concurs with Forbes about the importance of 'the language on stage, the story, and the vibe,' adding that 'relevance to today's world, urban or otherwise, is a major part' of the hip-hop theater experience. |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Other cultural markers of [[hip-hop]] such as [[performance poetry|spoken word]], [[beatboxing]], and [[hip-hop dance]] can be included as well although they are not always present. What is most important is the language of the theatrical piece and the plot's relevance to the world.<ref name=mania/> Danny Hoch, founder of the Hip-Hop Theater Festival, further defines it as such: "Hip-hop theatre must fit into the realm of theatrical performance, and it must be ''by, about and for'' the hip-hop generation, participants in hip-hop culture, or both."<ref name=aesthetic>{{cite web|last=Hoch |first=Danny |title=Towards a Hip-Hop Aesthetic: A Manifesto for the Hip-Hop Arts Movement |url=http://www.dannyhoch.com/pdf/TowardsAHip-HopAesthetic.pdf |date=September 14, 2005 |work=DannyHoch.com |accessdate=November 3, 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/628bIFIEM?url=http://www.dannyhoch.com/pdf/TowardsAHip-HopAesthetic.pdf |archivedate=October 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
Hip-hop theater productions appear in a wide range of platforms including single performances, week-long festivals, and traveling [[Theatre#Repertory companies|repertory]] companies. [[Marc Bamuthi Joseph]] is an award-winning [[spoken word]] poet and dancer who has been commissioned several times to create and direct single hip-hop theater works. [[British people|British]] choreographer Jonzi D is the artistic director of the London-based Breakin' Convention, a week long hip-hop theater festival. [[Rennie Harris]], Mourad Merzouki, and Victor Quijada are artistic directors who run hip-hop theater companies in the U.S., France, and Canada respectively. The Rock Steady Crew, Magnificent Force, and the Rhythm Technicians pioneered this theatrical genre which started in the United States.
==History== Though hip-hop culture has managed to establish itself on film, on television, in fashion, in music, and in the dance industry, it has not gained the same momentum in theater. Stage productions are few in number but growing.<ref name=voice>{{cite news|last=Weber |first=Bruce |title=Hip-Hop's Distinct Voice Is Reshaping Theater |work=The New York Times |date=June 25, 2002 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/06/25/theater/critic-s-notebook-hip-hop-s-distinct-voice-is-reshaping-theater.html?scp=3&sq=Hip-Hop%27s%20Distinct%20Voice%20Is%20Reshaping%20Theater%22.%20&st=cse |accessdate=October 25, 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/628bU1ijR?url=http://www.nytimes.com/2002/06/25/theater/critic-s-notebook-hip-hop-s-distinct-voice-is-reshaping-theater.html?scp=3&sq=Hip-Hop%27s%20Distinct%20Voice%20Is%20Reshaping%20Theater%22.%20&st=cse |archivedate=October 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The first hip-hop stage shows were 1990's [[off Broadway]] [[musical theatre|musical]] ''So! What Happens Now?'' and 1995's ''Jam on the Groove'' which were co-authored, co-directed, and co-choreographed by Jorge "Popmaster Fabel" Pabon and Steffan "[[Mr. Wiggles]]" Clemente.<ref>{{cite web|last=Chang |first=Jeff |title=Dancing on the Through-Line |url=http://www.colum.edu/administrative_offices/Academic_Research/PDF_folder/rennie_harrris.pdf |work=Colum.edu |accessdate=November 29, 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/63ZTHb6O1?url=http://www.colum.edu/administrative_offices/Academic_Research/PDF_folder/rennie_harrris.pdf |archivedate=November 30, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |last=Chang |first=Jeff |title=Total Chaos: The Art and Aesthetics of Hip-Hop |publisher=BasicCivitas |location=New York City|year=2006 |page=26 |isbn=0465009093}}</ref> [[Rock Steady Crew]], Magnificent Force, and the Rhythm Technicians performed in both shows.<ref>{{cite news|last=Milosheff |first=Peter |title=Rock Steady Crew 32nd Anniversary |work=The Bronx Times |date=July 7, 2008 |url=http://www.bronx.com/news/entertainment/entertainment_music/290.html |accessdate=August 25, 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/628bZSdBE?url=http://www.bronx.com/news/entertainment/entertainment_music/290.html |archivedate=October 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Gardner |first1=Elysa |last2=Eccles |first2=Andrew |date=September 1992 |title=Off the Streets and onto Center Stage |journal=Rolling Stone |issn=0035-791X}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Pareles |first=Jon |title=Theater In Review |work=The New York Times |date=November 18, 1995 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/18/arts/theater-in-review-045713.html |accessdate=August 24, 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/628bjnlUX?url=http://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/18/arts/theater-in-review-045713.html |archivedate=October 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Aside from the pioneers in New York City was Lorenzo "Rennie" Harris' Puremovement (RHPM) hip-hop theater company which Harris founded in 1992 in [[Philadelphia]].<ref>{{cite news |last=Parker |first=Janine |title=Hip-hop dance party at Jacob's Pillow |work=[[The Boston Globe]] |date=August 8, 2009 |url=http://www.boston.com/ae/theater_arts/articles/2009/08/08/hip_hop_dance_party_at_jacobs_pillow/ |accessdate=August 15, 2009}}</ref> The company has toured all over the world showcasing its original works such as ''March of the Antmen'', ''P-Funk'', ''Endangered Species'', ''Facing Mekka'', and ''Rome & Jewels''.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Gottschild |first=Brenda |date=February 2007 |title=Prince ScareKrow and the Emerald City: Rennie Harris’s Hip Hop Life |work=Dance |url=http://dancemagazine.com/issues/February-2007/Rennie-Harris |issn=0011-6009 |accessdate=August 15, 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/628c7KAOa?url=http://www.dancemagazine.com/issues/February-2007/Prince-ScareKrow-and-the-Emerald-City- |archivedate=October 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> RHPM also organizes the annual Illadelph Legends Festival which brings together the [[innovator|pioneers]]—the people who were [[b-boying]], [[locking (dance)|locking]], and [[popping]] in the 1970s when these styles were developed—and respected practitioners of hip-hop dance to teach master classes, give lecture demonstrations, and participate in panel discussions.<ref>{{cite web|title=About Illadelph |url=http://www.rhpm.org/illadelph.php |work=RHPM.org |accessdate=August 15, 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/628cML10A?url=http://www.rhpm.org/illadelph.php |archivedate=October 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
==Repertory companies== Other hip-hop theater companies were founded in the 1990s. Compagnie [[wikt:Käfig|Käfig]] is a French hip-hop theater company of mostly [[Algeria]]n descent founded in 1995 by Mourad Merzouki.<ref name=sizzle>{{cite web|title=France’s Compagnie Kafig exports theatrical street sizzle in the North American premiere of Corps est Graphique at the National Arts Centre |url=http://www.nac-cna.ca/en/news/viewnews.cfm?ID=648&cat=catDance |date=February 5, 2004 |work=nac-cna.ca |accessdate=October 12, 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/628cT08Tn?url=http://www.nac-cna.ca/en/news/viewnews.cfm?ID=648&cat=catDance |archivedate=October 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Their performances mix standard [[b-boying]], [[locking (dance)|locking]], and [[popping]] with [[capoeira]], mime, and gymnastics.<ref name=sizzle/> They use the same fusion in music by mixing [[rap music]] with [[classical music]] and [[Flamenco guitar|Andalusian guitar]].<ref name=sizzle/> While on tour in the U.S. they performed at [[Jacob's Pillow]] in Massachusetts and at the [[Joyce Theater]] in New York.<ref>{{cite news|last=Kisselgoff |first=Anna |title=Hip-Hop Head-Spinning, but With a French Twist |work=The New York Times |date=May 16, 2002 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/05/16/arts/dance-review-hip-hop-head-spinning-but-with-a-french-twist.html?scp=1&sq=Hip-Hop%20Head-Spinning,%20but%20With%20a%20French%20Twist&st=cse |accessdate=October 17, 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/628cZvpgl?url=http://www.nytimes.com/2002/05/16/arts/dance-review-hip-hop-head-spinning-but-with-a-french-twist.html?scp=1&sq=Hip-Hop%20Head-Spinning%2C%20but%20With%20a%20French%20Twist&st=cse |archivedate=October 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Compagnie Kafig And Full Circle Souljahz. - Review - dance review |url=http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m1083/is_1_74/ai_58492346/?tag=content;col1 |date=January 2000 |work=BNet.com |publisher=''Dance'' magazine |accessdate=October 12, 2009 | first=Kate | last=Mattingly}}</ref> [[Bintou Dembélé]] performed at the Joyce Theater in New York with Mourad Merzouki's Compagnie Käfig in 2002.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2002/05/16/arts/dance-review-hip-hop-head-spinning-but-with-a-french-twist.html|title=DANCE REVIEW; Hip-Hop Head-Spinning, But With a French Twist|last=Kisselgoff|first=Anna|date=2002-05-16|newspaper=The New York Times|access-date=2017-02-19|issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=|first=|year=|title=Un témoignage de Bintou Dembele, " S/T/R/A/T/E/S. Trente ans de Hip-Hop dans le corps "|url=|journal=Africultures|volume=2014/3 (n° 99 - 100)|pages= 250–261|via=Cairn}}</ref> That same year she created her own dance company, which she describes as being mainly inspired by [[Pina Bausch|Pina Bausch's]] notion of 'danced theater'.<ref name=":0" /><ref name="dansercanalhistorique">{{Cite web|url=https://dansercanalhistorique.com/2014/02/20/bintou-dembele-et-la-danse-des-sauvages/|title=Bintou Dembélé et la danse des sauvages|last=dansercanalhistorique|date=2014-02-20|website=Dansercanalhistorique|access-date=2017-02-20}}</ref>
The Groovaloos are a hip-hop theater company based in Los Angeles that was founded by Bradley "Shooz" Rapier. They started out in 1999 as a [[Hip-hop dance#Dance crews|dance crew]] and eventually developed a stage show called ''Groovaloo'' that is a series of stories based on the true life experiences of the dancers.<ref>{{cite web|title=About the Show |url=http://groovaloo.com/about.php |date= |work=Groovaloo.com |accessdate=July 30, 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/628dosTjo?url=http://groovaloo.com/about.php |archivedate=October 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Company members include Edmundo "Poe One" Loayza, Rynan "Kid Rainen" Paguio from [[JabbaWockeeZ]], and Teresa "Rag Doll" Espinosa from [[Beat Freaks]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Based On The Lives Of... |url=http://www.groovaloo.com/meetShooz.php |date= |work=Groovaloo.com |accessdate=October 17, 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/628e8OROU?url=http://www.groovaloo.com/meetShooz.php |archivedate=October 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
RUBBERBANDance Group (RBDG) was founded in 2002 in [[Montreal]] by Los Angeles native Victor Quijada.<ref>{{cite news|last=Osterweis Scott |first=Ariel |title=Translating the Cipher |work=ArielOsterweis.com |date=August 29, 2008 |url=http://arielosterweis.com/publications/feature-articles/translating-the-cipher/ |accessdate=October 2, 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/628eRCtg5?url=http://arielosterweis.com/publications/feature-articles/translating-the-cipher/ |archivedate=October 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name=rbdg>{{cite news|last=Schwyzer |first=Elizabeth |title=Victor Quijada Keeps Stretching Dance's Boundaries |work=Santa Barbara Independent |date=January 31, 2008 |url=http://www.independent.com/news/2008/jan/31/victor-quijada-keeps-stretching-dances-boundaries/ |accessdate=March 5, 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/628eYnbZC?url=http://www.independent.com/news/2008/jan/31/victor-quijada-keeps-stretching-dances-boundaries/ |archivedate=October 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Quijada first started dancing as a [[b-boy]] in [[Baldwin Park, California]].<ref name=rbdg/> He studied [[modern dance]] in high school and after graduating went on to become a professional dancer under [[Twyla Tharp]] and Les Grands Ballets Canadiens de Montréal.<ref name=rbdg/><ref name=balletbreak>{{cite journal|last=Sommers |first=Sally |url=http://www.dancemagazine.com/issues/january-2012/Balletic-Breakin |title=Balletic Breakin' |work=Dance |issn=0011-6009 |date=January 2012 |accessdate=January 30, 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6E447Lfxf?url=http://www.dancemagazine.com/issues/january-2012/Balletic-Breakin |archivedate=January 30, 2013 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> He started RBDG after leaving the Montreal ballet. ''[[The New York Times]]'' called the style of dance his company performs "post hip-hop" because it's a fusion of hip-hop dance and ballet.<ref name=rbdg/>
==Independent performances== Marc Bamuthi Joseph is an award-winning spoken word poet and [[playwright]] who frequently directs independent hip-hop theater productions.<ref name=speak>{{cite web|title=Marc Bamuthi Joseph: A Leading Voice in Performance and Arts Education |url=http://www.speakoutnow.org/userdata_display.php?modin=50&uid=165 |work=SpeakOutNow.org |accessdate=November 3, 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/628eejjdT?url=http://www.speakoutnow.org/userdata_display.php?modin=50&uid=165 |archivedate=October 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Some of his works include ''Word Becomes Flesh'', ''De/Cipher'', and ''No Man's Land''. He collaborated with Rennie Harris in 2007 to create ''Scourge'', a play about [[Haiti]]'s social-economic struggles. Joseph directed the play while Harris served as the choreographer.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Living Word Project: Scorge |url=http://www.youthspeaks.org/lwp_projects_scourge.html |work=YouthSpeaks.org |accessdate=October 12, 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/628erGw3H?url=http://www.youthspeaks.org/lwp_projects_scourge.html |archivedate=October 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name=party>{{cite news|last=Vigil |first=Delfin |title=Hip-hop theater is a party for the people |url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/chronicle/archive/2005/04/24/PKG69CBJM31.DTL&type=performance |date=April 24, 2005 |work=San Francisco Chronicle |accessdate=November 3, 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/628eycnZQ?url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=%2Fchronicle%2Farchive%2F2005%2F04%2F24%2FPKG69CBJM31.DTL&type=performance |archivedate=October 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> In 2008, he created ''the break/s'' which is based on the book ''[[Can't Stop Won't Stop (book)|Can't Stop Won't Stop]]'' by [[Jeff Chang (journalist)|Jeff Chang]].<ref name=speak/>
Other solo hip-hop theater artists include [[Sarah Jones (stage actress)|Sarah Jones]] who headlined the first Hip-Hop Theater Festival<ref name=mania/> and award-winning playwright [[Will Power (performer)|Will "Power" Wylie]] who collaborated with Danny Hock on his one-man play ''Flow''.<ref>{{cite news|last=McCarter |first=Jeremy |title=THEATER; Hip-Hop and Musicals: Made for Each Other? |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/06/08/theater/theater-hip-hop-and-musicals-made-for-each-other.html?pagewanted=1 |date=June 8, 2003 |work=The New York Times |accessdate=November 3, 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/628f6X7QJ?url=http://www.nytimes.com/2003/06/08/theater/theater-hip-hop-and-musicals-made-for-each-other.html?pagewanted=1 |archivedate=October 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Also, West Coast feminist writer/performer [[Aya de Leon]] whose award-winning show "Thieves in the Temple: The Reclaiming of Hip Hop" focused on fighting sexism and consumerism in hip hop.<ref>{{cite web |last=Harmanci |first=Reyhan |date=March 15, 2007 |title=Responding in kind / 'Thieves in the Temple' / Aya de Leon took a stand when hip-hop culture's sexism went too far |url=http://www.sfgate.com/thingstodo/article/Responding-in-kind-Thieves-in-the-Temple-2570665.php |work=San Francisco Gate |accessdate=March 24, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20151009073653/http://www.sfgate.com/thingstodo/article/Responding-in-kind-Thieves-in-the-Temple-2570665.php |archivedate=October 9, 2015}}</ref>
==Festivals== *Rencontres de la Villette is a two-week hip-hop theater festival started in France in 1996. Unlike the other theater companies mentioned, Recontres de la Villette was started with the help of government [[Subsidy|subsidies]] from the Ministry of Culture to promote [[the arts]].<ref>{{cite journal |last=Shapiro |first=Roberta |year=2004 |title=The Aesthetics of Institutionalization: Breakdancing in France |journal=The Journal of Arts Management Law and Society |volume=33 |issue=4 |page=321 |doi=10.3200/JAML.33.4.316-335}}</ref> *Hip-Hop Theater Festival was founded in 2000 in New York<ref name=kennedy>{{cite web|title=HIP-HOP THEATER FESTIVAL |url=http://www.kennedy-center.org/explorer/artists/?entity_id=19864&source_type=B |work=Kennedy-Center.org |accessdate=August 27, 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/628gDU09n?url=http://www.kennedy-center.org/explorer/artists/?entity_id=19864&source_type=B |archivedate=October 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> by playwright and actor [[Danny Hoch]].<ref name=mania/><ref name=voice/> The week-long festival starts in Washington, D.C. and tours annually to New York, San Francisco, and Chicago.<ref name=kennedy/><ref>{{cite news|last=Wilson |first=Timothy |title=Hip-Hop Theater Festival Reaches Out to All Ages |work=The Washington Post |date=July 16, 2009 |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/07/15/AR2009071501456_2.html |accessdate=2009-08-27 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/628gIuIec?url=http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2009/07/15/AR2009071501456_2.html |archivedate=October 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> *[[Breakin' Convention]] was started in 2004 by playwright and dancer Jonzi D and is housed annually at [[Sadler's Wells Theatre]] in London.<ref>{{cite web|title=About us |url=http://www.breakinconvention.com/about-us |date=2009 |work=BreakinConvention.com |accessdate=August 25, 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/628gXGsLS?url=http://www.breakinconvention.com/about-us |archivedate=October 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Every year starts off with a three-day festival in London. After the London festival, the convention tours to other cities in the United Kingdom. *[[Hip Hop goes Theatre]] is a theater festival that was started in 2008 by dancers Alexander Wengler and Sergej Pumper in Salzburg, Austria.
==See also== {{Portal|Theatre}} *[[Hip hop culture|Hip-hop culture]] *''[[Into the Hoods]]'' *''[[In the Heights]]'' *''[[Hamilton (musical)]]'' *''[[Holler If Ya Hear Me (musical)]]''
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=4183762 Will Power, Telling Stories through 'Hip Hop Theatre'] podcast at [[NPR]].org
{{hiphop}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Hip-Hop Theater}} [[Category:Theatrical genres]] [[Category:Theatre]] [[Category:Theatre in the United States]] [[Category:History of hip hop]] [[Category:Performing arts]]

Electric Spoofaloo
My Date | website = http://www.take180.com/show/I_Heart_Vampires/h1a }} '''''I Heart Vampires''''' (Often stylized as '''''I <3 Vampires''''') is a [[web television]] series produced by Take180 (a subsidiary of [[The Walt Disney Company]]).{{cite news | url=http://news.tubefilter.tv/2008/09/03/take180-blasts-off-with-180-second-quickies | title= Take180 Blasts Off With 180 Second Quickies | publisher=''[[Tubefilter]]'' | date=Feb 5, 2009 | accessdate=Mar 16, 2010}}{{cite news | url=http://news.tubefilter.tv/2009/04/01/take180-launches-three-new-interactive-series-vampires-date-and-spoofaloo/ | title= Take180 Launches Three New Interactive Series, ‘Vampires,’ ‘Date’ and ‘Spoofaloo’ | publisher=''[[Tubefilter]]'' | date=Apr 1, 2009 | accessdate=Mar 16, 2010}} The series consists of a first season of 22 episodes which ran from March 19, 2009 until September 11, 2009, a second season of 20 episodes which premiered on January 28, 2010, as well as two derivative series that run concurrently with the second season, and concluded on June 4, 2010. The series is well received, and is the first non-variety sketch show on the site to make it past a first season.{{Cite news | url = http://theweband1.blogspot.com/2009/08/i-3-vampires-episodes-1-17.html | title = I <3 Vampires (episodes 1-17) | date = 2009-08-14 | work = [[The Web and 1]] | accessdate = 2010-03-16}} The show, like many on the site, takes fan submissions and integrated them into each episode. ==Plot== The show is a parody of the fandom that surrounds popular vampire franchises like ''[[Twilight (novel series)|Twilight]]''. ===Season One=== Corbin and Luci, two best friends, run "I <3 Vampires" - a fansite for their favorite book, ''Confessions of a High School Vampire'', for which Corbin makes daily [[vlogging|vlogs]] regarding the book series. When Luci receives an anonymous e-mail containing the first six chapters of the upcoming book in the ''Confessions'' series (derived from the online leak of part of the fifth [[Twilight (novel series)|Twilight]] book, [[Midnight Sun (Stephenie Meyer novel)|Midnight Sun]]), the best friends are so excited that Corbin posts the chapters on "I <3 Vampires" without thinking about the consequences. When the books' author, Siona McCabre, learns that chapters of her new book have been leaked, and announces that she has halted the publication of the book indefinitely, Corbin and Luci take it upon themselves to find Siona and apologize, hoping that Siona will continue with the book's publication. With the help of Corbin's annoying neighbour, Wyatt, the three go on a quest to find Siona, which proves to be more difficult - and much more complicated - than they had originally thought. ===Season Two=== A year ago, Corbin and Luci found out that their favorite book, ''Confessions of a High School Vampire'', was more real than they ever could have imagined. Now the two are no longer friends, and have abandoned "I <3 Vampires," the fansite they created for ''Confessions''. They have also broken up with their supernatural boyfriends, Nick and Wyatt, and so Corbin is surprised when Siona McCabre, author of ''Confessions'' and mother to Corbin's ex-boyfriend Nick, asks Corbin to help her find Nick, who has been missing for several weeks. Corbin refuses. Three days later, Corbin learns that Siona has been killed, and so she makes her first vlog since abandoning "I <3 Vampires," in which she apologizes for leaving the fansite without an explanation. Corbin then goes missing, and it's up to her college roommate, ''Confessions'' fan Sam, to reunite Luci and Wyatt so that the three of them can find Corbin together. ==Hiatus and Series Future== At the conclusion of the second season there was not any news on whether or not there would be a third season. Cherilyn Wilson and Alli Kinzel later stated in a YouTube video that there would not be another season coming in the foreseeable future as they have not been contacted about continuing the series, despite high fan demand.{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FcYeg8Ob510|title=corbin and sam vlog again |author=Alli Kinzel|publisher=[[YouTube]]|accessdate=June 15, 2011}} On June 15, Josh Nuncio announced on Twitter that both seasons with cast commentary and alternate endings would be available on [[Amazon.com]].{{cite web|url=https://twitter.com/JoshDNun/status/81112553031352321|title=I<3Vampires fans we just finished filming the new cast commentary and both season will soon be available at Amazon with alternative endings|author=Josh Nuncio|publisher=[[Twitter]]|accessdate=June 15, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140601081210/https://twitter.com/JoshDNun/status/81112553031352321#|archive-date=2014-06-01|dead-url=yes|df=}} ==Book== In 2011 [[Disney Publishing Worldwide]] published ''I Heart Vampires: Birth (A Confessions of a High School Vampire Novel)'' which was written by Siona McCabre. It is the same book that Corbin and Luci read in the series. The book is about the student Noah Vance who discoveres two bite marks in a morning after a high school party. He realizes that he is turning into a vampire.{{cite web|url=http://www.barnesandnoble.com/w/i-heart-vampires-siona-mccabre/1113019032?ean=9781423167686 |title=I Heart Vampires: Birth (A Confessions of a High School Vampire Novel) [NOOK Book] |publisher=barnesandnoble.com |accessdate=30 October 2014}} ==Cast== *Cherilyn Wilson as Corbin *[[Erin Way]] as Luci *Adam Chambers as Wyatt *Alli Kinzel as Sam *Josh Nuncio as Nick McCabre *[[Martha Hackett]] as Siona McCabre ==Awards and nominations== === Awards=== ''[[Webby Awards]]:'' * 2010: Online Film & Video Best Use of Interactive Video ''(T180 Studios'' / ''[[The Walt Disney Company]]''){{cite web |url=http://www.webbyawards.com/winners/2010/online-film-video/performance-craft-categories/best-use-of-interactive-video/i-3-vampires |title=Best use of interactive video. I <3 vampires |publisher=webbyawards.com |accessdate=11 April 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150403125746/http://www.webbyawards.com/winners/2010/online-film-video/performance-craft-categories/best-use-of-interactive-video/i-3-vampires/# |archive-date=2015-04-03 |dead-url=yes |df= }} === Nominations=== ''[[Streamy Award]]:'' * 2010: Best Interactive Experience in a Web Series (''T180 Studios'' / ''The Walt Disney Compan''y){{cite web|url=http://www.streamys.org/nominees-winners/2010-nominees |title=2nd Annual Nominees & Winners. |publisher=streamys.org |accessdate=11 April 2015}} ==See also== *[[Vampire film]] *[[List of vampire television series]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100323162552/http://www.take180.com/show/I_Heart_Vampires/h1a I <3 Vampires on Take180] - official site * {{IMDb title|1414707|I <3 Vampires}} [[Category:2009 web series debuts]] [[Category:2010 web series endings]] [[Category:Comedy web series]] [[Category:Horror fiction web series]] [[Category:American web series]]

{{Infobox person |name=Kazem El-Solh |image=Kazem El Solh.jpg |birth_date = 1904 |birth_place = Beirut |death_date = 25 December 1976 |nationality = [[Lebanese nationality law|Lebanese]] |occupation = Political activist, politician, diplomat, newspaper founder }}
'''Kazem El-Solh''' (1904 – 25 December 1976) was a Lebanese politician, a diplomat and the founder of a political party and a newspaper. He was a member of parliament in Lebanon and served as the country's ambassador to Iraq. He hails from a prominent [[Sunni Islam in Lebanon|Sunni Muslim]] family which gave Lebanon four prime ministers, his brother [[Takieddine Solh]], as well as [[Riad Solh]], [[Sami as-Solh|Sami Solh]] and [[Rachid Solh]]. The Solh family is originally from the ancient port city of [[Sidon]] in southern Lebanon.
==Career== Kazem El-Solh served as Lebanese Ambassador in Baghdad from 1947 to 1960, leaving Iraq a year after the coup ousting the Hashemite monarchy in the country.<ref>{{cite book |title=Lebanon and Arabism |publisher=Raghid el-Solh, I.B. Tauris Publishers |date= 2004|url=https://books.google.ae/books?id=49z7AFqIE2IC&pg=PA147&lpg=PA147&dq=kazem+solh+ambassador+iraq&source=bl&ots=44hRqnrKx6&sig=Xf5cMa3_RJIZ30Ezad-PXy80RAw&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiWn8zvyZHbAhXBtBQKHVd7CxcQ6AEIPjAI#v=onepage&q=kazem%20solh%20ambassador%20iraq&f=false}}</ref> In 1960-1964, he was a member of the [[Lebanese Parliament]], representing the eastern region of [[Zahle]]. He was also the head of the parliamentary foreign affairs committee. Prior to that, Kazem El-Solh was a staunch activist for Arab nationalism and the region's independence from foreign powers. He also established the Arab Nationalist Party in 1935.
In 1936, El-Solh wrote a paper during the Coastal Conference, published later, and which was the precursor to Lebanon's [[National Pact]], promoting Lebanese coexistence. His paper is generally considered as one of the foundations of the Lebanese Constitution and it’s citizen’s charter.<ref>{{cite web |title=Actualité du manifeste de Kazem el-Solh en 1936 |publisher=L'Orient Le Jour |date=April 18, 2008 |url=https://www.lorientlejour.com/article/587924/Actualite_du_manifestede_Kazem_el-Solh_en_1936%252AProfesseur_Antoine_MESSARRA.html}}</ref>
In 1943-1947, he set up a law practice in downtown Beirut and in 1944-1960 he formed a political party called Al Nida, together with other prominent intellectuals and his brother [[Takieddin el-Solh]], who later became prime minister.
===''Al Nida''=== In 1930, he was the founding owner of the daily newspaper Al Nida (The Appeal) in Beirut, to which his brothers contributed articles. <ref>{{cite web |title=47 Years since the Assassination of Journalist Kamel Mroueh |publisher=The Monthly Magazzine |date=May 9, 2013 |url=http://monthlymagazine.com/article-print_1266_print}}</ref> The paper ceased being published in 1940.
==Personal life== Kazem El-Solh was born in 1904, in Beirut. He attended the [[International College, Beirut]], then studied at the Jesuit School, also in Beirut, before graduating with a law degree from the University of Damascus. In 1934, he married his first cousin Yesser Kamel El-Solh. They had four children: Hannah, Khaldoun, Nawal and [[Raghid El-Solh]]. He died on December 25, 1976.
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[https://www.lorientlejour.com/article/587924/Actualite_du_manifestede_Kazem_el-Solh_en_1936%252AProfesseur_Antoine_MESSARRA.html ''L'Orient Le Jour''], Beirut, Lebanon, April 18, 2008. *[https://books.google.ae/books?id=49z7AFqIE2IC&pg=PA147&lpg=PA147&dq=kazem+solh+ambassador+iraq&source=bl&ots=44hRqnrKx6&sig=Xf5cMa3_RJIZ30Ezad-PXy80RAw&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwiWn8zvyZHbAhXBtBQKHVd7CxcQ6AEIPjAI#v=onepage&q=kazem%20solh%20ambassador%20iraq&f=false ''Lebanon and Arabism''], By Raghid el-Solh, I.B. Tauris Publishers, 2004, page 147.
{{authority control}}

revision.comment: Importing Wikidata [[Wikipedia:Short description|short description]]: "Wikimedia list article" ([[User:Galobtter/Shortdesc helper|Shortdesc helper]])
revision.text:
{{short description|Wikimedia list article}} This is a '''list of [[television]] programs in which one character was played by multiple actors'''. In numerous television programs, producers have cast multiple actors for the part of the same character.<ref name=Besc>{{citation |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=lPMiAQAAIAAJ |page=1339 |title=Beacham's encyclopedia of social change |volume=3 |author=Veryan Khan|isbn=9780933833661 |date=2001-09 }}</ref> This list does not include different actors playing the same [[Fictional character|character]] at significantly different ages (as in [[Flashback (narrative)|flashback]]s), but it does include actors playing the character continuously as the character ages. Actors are listed in chronological order, where possible. For a list specific to soap operas, see [[list of soap opera recasts]].
==#== ''[[The 4400]]''. Character: [[Lily Tyler]]. Actresses: [[Laura Allen]], [[Tippi Hedren]].
==A== *''[[The A-Team]]'' (1983–1987). Character: Lt. [[Templeton "Faceman" Peck]]. Actors: [[Tim Dunigan]] (in the pilot), [[Dirk Benedict]] *''[[Adventures of Superman (TV series)|Adventures of Superman]]'' Character: [[Lois Lane]]. Actresses: [[Phyllis Coates]], [[Noel Neill]]. *''[[The Adventures of William Tell]]'' (1950s). Character: Gessler's second in command, Frederick. Actors: [[Derren Nesbitt]] (first six episodes), [[Willoughby Gray]] (seventh episode), [[Jack Watling]] *''[[Alice (TV series)|Alice]]'' Character: Tommy Hyatt. Actors: [[Alfred Lutter]] (pilot - carry-over from original movie [[Alice Doesn't Live Here Anymore]]), [[Philip McKeon]] (rest of series) *''[[All in the Family]]'' **Character: Gloria Bunker. Actresses: Kelly Jean Peters (first pilot), [[Candice Azzara]] (second pilot), [[Sally Struthers]]. **Character: [[Lionel Jefferson]]. Actors: [[D'Urville Martin]] (pilots), [[Mike Evans (actor)|Mike Evans]]. *''[['Allo 'Allo!]]'' **Character: [[Captain Alberto Bertorelli]]. Actors: [[Gavin Richards]] (1987–1989), [[Roger Kitter]] (1991). **Character: [[Monsieur Ernest LeClerc]]. Actors: [[Derek Royle]] (1989), [[Robin Parkinson]] (1991–1992), (2007). **Character: [[Herr Otto Flick]]. Actors: [[Richard Gibson]] (1984–1992), [[David Janson]] (1992). *''[[Another Period]]''. Character: Hortence Bellacort. Actresses: [[Artemis Pebdani]] (pilot), [[Lauren Ash]] (first season), [[Lauren Flans]]. * ''[[Arrow (TV series)|Arrow]]'' (2012-present): Character: [[Sara Lance]]. Actresses: [[Jacqueline MacInnes Wood]] (pilot), [[Caity Lotz]] (season 2 - present)
==B== * ''[[Babylon 5]]''. Character: [[Anna Sheridan]]. Actresses: [[Beth Toussaint]], [[Melissa Gilbert]]. * ''[[Back to You (TV series)|Back to You]]'' (2007–2008). Character: Gracie Carr. Actresses: [[Laura Marano]], [[Lily Jackson]]. * ''[[Barbary Coast (TV series)|Barbary Coast]]''. Character: Cash Conover. Actors: [[Doug McClure]], [[Dennis Cole]] (Pilot only) * ''[[Batman (TV series)|Batman]]''. **Character: [[Catwoman]]. Actresses: [[Julie Newmar]], [[Lee Meriwether]] (1966 film only), [[Eartha Kitt]]. **Character: [[Riddler]]. Actors: [[Frank Gorshin]] and [[John Astin]]. **Character: [[Mr. Freeze]]. Actors: [[George Sanders]], [[Otto Preminger]], and [[Eli Wallach]] * ''[[Being Human (UK TV series)|Being Human]]''. **Character: [[John Mitchell (Being Human)|John Mitchell]]. Actors: [[Aidan Turner]], [[Guy Flanagan]] ([[Pilot (Being Human)|Pilot]] only). **Character: [[Annie Sawyer]]. Actresses: [[Lenora Crichlow]], [[Andrea Riseborough]] ([[Pilot (Being Human)|Pilot]] only). **Character: [[William Herrick (Being Human)|William Herrick]]. Actors: [[Jason Watkins (actor)|Jason Watkins]], [[Adrian Lester]] ([[Pilot (Being Human)|Pilot]] only). **Character: [[List of Being Human characters#Lauren Drake|Lauren Drake]]. Actresses: [[Annabel Scholey]], [[Dominique McElligott]] ([[Pilot (Being Human)|Pilot]] only) * ''[[Bette (TV series)|Bette]]''. **Character: Roy. Actors: [[Kevin Dunn]] and [[Robert Hays]]. **Character: Rose. Actresses: [[Lindsay Lohan]], Marina Malota * ''[[The Beverly Hillbillies]]''. Character: Jethro Bodine. Actors: [[Max Baer, Jr.]], Ray Young (The Return of the Beverly Hillbillies). * ''[[Bewitched]]''. **Character: [[Santa Claus]]. Actors: [[Cecil Kellaway]], [[Don Beddoe]] (1 episode each). **Character: [[Darrin Stephens]]. Actors: [[Dick York]] (1964–1969), [[Dick Sargent]] (1969–1972). **Character: [[Gladys Kravitz]]. Actresses: [[Alice Pearce]] (1964–1966), [[Sandra Gould]] (1966–1971). **Character: Tabitha Stephens. Actresses: Cynthia Black (1966), Heidi and Laura Gentry (1966), Tamar and Julie Young (1966), [[Diane Murphy]] (1966–1968), [[Erin Murphy]] (1966–1972). **Character: Louise Tate. Actresses: [[Irene Vernon]] (1964–1966), [[Kasey Rogers]] (1966–1972) * ''[[Big Love]]''. ** Character: Tancy Henrickson. Actresses: [[Jolean Wejbe]] (2006–2009), [[Bella Thorne]] (2010)<ref>https://ohnotheydidnt.livejournal.com/43466027.html</ref> * ''[[Blake's 7]]''. Character: [[Travis (Blake's 7)|Travis]]. Actors: [[Stephen Greif]], [[Brian Croucher]] * ''[[Boy Meets World]]''. **Character: Morgan Matthews. Actresses: [[Lily Nicksay]] (1993–1995), Lindsay Ridgeway (1995–2000). **Character: Jedidiah Lawrence (Topanga's father). Actors: [[Peter Tork]], [[Mark Harelik]] * ''[[The Brady Bunch]]''. **Character: Marcia Brady. Actresses: [[Maureen McCormick]], [[Leah Ayres]] (''[[The Bradys]]''). **Character: Jan Brady. Actresses: [[Eve Plumb]], [[Geri Reischl]] (''[[The Brady Bunch Variety Hour]]''). **Character: Cindy Brady. Actresses: [[Susan Olsen]], [[Jennifer Runyon]] (''[[A Very Brady Christmas]]''). * ''[[Buffy the Vampire Slayer (TV series)|Buffy the Vampire Slayer]]''. Character: Nikki Wood. Actresses: April Weeden-Washington, [[K. D. Aubert]]
==C== * ''[[Cadfael (TV series)|Cadfael]]''. Character: Hugh Beringar. Actors: [[Sean Pertwee]] (four episodes), [[Eoin McCarthy]] five episodes and [[Anthony Green (actor)|Anthony Green]] for the final three episodes. * ''[[Charmed]]''. Character: Victor Halliwell. Actors: [[Anthony Denison]] (one episode), [[James Read]] * ''[[Cheers]]''. Character: Gary. Actors: Alternating between [[Joel Polis]] and [[Robert Desiderio]] * ''[[The Count of Monte Cristo (1998 miniseries)|The Count of Monte Cristo]]'' (1998). **Character: [[Edmond Dantès]]. Actors: [[Gérard Depardieu]] and [[Guillaume Depardieu]]. **Character: Mercedes Igualada. Actresses: [[Ornella Muti]] and [[Naike Rivelli]] * ''[[Cuckoo (TV series)|Cuckoo]]''. Character: Rachel Thompson. Actresses: [[Tamla Kari]] (series one), Esther Smith.
==D== *''[[Dallas (1978 TV series)|Dallas]]''. **Character: Miss Ellie Ewing. Actresses: [[Barbara Bel Geddes]] (1978–1984, 1985–1990) and [[Donna Reed]] (1984–1985).<ref name=jts/> **Character: Jenna Wade. Actresses: [[Morgan Fairchild]] and [[Priscilla Presley]]. **Character: Kristin Stewart. Actresses: [[Mary Crosby]] and [[Colleen Camp]]. *''[[Dark Shadows]]'' (1966–1971). Character: Willie Loomis. Actors: James Hall (4 episodes), [[John Karlen]] (106 episodes) *''[[Days of Our Lives]]''. Character: Roman Brady. Actors: [[Wayne Northrop]], [[Josh Taylor]] *''[[Diff'rent Strokes]]''. The '''London Opera Glass Company''' was officially formed in [[London]], [[England]] on 20 May 1913 to produce [[opera glasses]] for theatres in London.<ref name="company-info">{{cite web | url=http://www.companiesintheuk.co.uk/ltd/the-london-opera-glass-company | title=The London Opera Glass Company Limited | work=Companies in the UK | accessdate=May 8, 2012}}</ref><ref name="Team2014">{{cite book|author=National Quiz Team|title=The Only Quiz Book You Will Ever Need|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZJl-BAAAQBAJ&pg=PT177|date=9 October 2014|publisher=Random House|isbn=978-1-4735-1764-6|pages=177–}}</ref>
The company's purpose was to offer fashionable [[theatre]] goers in London's [[West End (London)|West End]], technology that had started in [[Vienna]] and [[Paris]] in the 19th century. Opera glasses were not new at the time of the company's formation. In fact they were a fashion accessory at the end of the 19th century and the beginning of the 20th century. It was not until 1912 that the London Opera Glass Company installed discrete dispensers on the backs of seats, enabling patrons to rent them for 6d (2{{frac|1|2}}p in today's money).
Since the formation of the company, around 11 million patrons have used its opera glasses to view theatre productions such as [[Noël Coward]]'s comic play ''[[Hay Fever]]'' in 1925 and ''[[The Phantom of the Opera (1986 musical)|The Phantom of the Opera]]'' musical by [[Andrew Lloyd Webber]]. In 2009, two major London theatres, the [[Comedy Theatre]] and the [[Savoy Theatre]], installed £1 opera glasses from the company throughout their auditoriums.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://archive.constantcontact.com/fs085/1101966345958/archive/1102666739235.html |title=Two famous London theatres get Opera Glasses in time for new productions |work=Theatre Views Newsletter | date=Summer 2009 | accessdate=May 9, 2012}}</ref> {{Asof|October 2011}}, around 1.8 million people have used the company's opera glasses at the [[Lyceum Theatre, London|Lyceum Theatre]] during performances of the ''[[Lion King (musical)|Lion King]]'' since it opened in October 1999.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://archive.constantcontact.com/fs085/1101966345958/archive/1107747364051.html | title=1.8 million views of Lion King | work=Theatre Views Newsletter | date=October 2011 | accessdate=May 9, 2012}}</ref>
The company is now based in [[Sandwich, Kent|Sandwich]], [[Kent]].<ref name="company-info" /> It supplies over 60 theatres in the [[United Kingdom]] and the distinctive red glasses are made in the UK.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.greenachiever.co.uk/newsletters/ga-newsletter-march-2012.pdf | title=Company Profiles: London Opera Glass Company | work=Green Achiever Newsletter | date=March 2012 | accessdate=May 10, 2012}}</ref> The company makes charitable donations, including to ''[[The Theatres Trust]]''<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.theatrestrust.org.uk/news/show/2895-london-opera-glass-company-donate-money-to-the-theatres-trust | title=London Opera Glass Company donate money to The Theatres Trust | publisher=[[The Theatres Trust]], UK | date=2 May 2011 | accessdate=May 8, 2012}}</ref> and the [[Marlowe Theatre]].<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.marlowetheatre.com/page/3132/Opera-glass-company-sets-sights-on-our-theatre/24 | title=Opera glass company sets sights on our theatre | publisher=[[The Marlowe Theatre]], UK | date=10 January 2011 | accessdate=May 9, 2012}}</ref>
London Opera Glass Company donated 30 pairs of glasses to the Wildlife Trust of South & West Wales for children to use.<ref name="wels_Dona">{{Cite web| title = Donated Opera Glasses| work = The Wildlife Trust of South and West Wales| accessdate = 2018-03-16| url = https://www.welshwildlife.org/eastglamnews/donated-opera-glasses/}}</ref>
